He hangs up, thoughtfully folds the note and puts it in h pocket, returns to the kitchen, leaving the door open. Fr front of the house comes the sound of a door opening and and Parnell comes from the outer office into Paul's priva

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (in the kitchen) What do you say there, counselor?

dialogues.speaker: PARNELL
dialogues.text: (sees the brown paper bag) What's in the brown paper bag?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: It could be a cabbage head.

dialogues.speaker: PARNELL
dialogues.text: But it wouldn't be.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: You're a suspicious man.

dialogues.speaker: PARNELL
dialogues.text: True. I'm everlastingly suspicious of and/or fascinated by the contents of brown paper bags. Shall I sneak a peek?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: You do that -- and uncork whatever you find, . Parnell peers into the paper bag. Paul enters with two gl and a pitcher of water.

dialogues.speaker: PARNELL
dialogues.text: Shall I pour? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Your privilege.

dialogues.speaker: PARNELL
dialogues.text: (pouring) My pleasure, sir. They drink, Paul goes to the piano, sits and begins to fo with some passages of jazz, Parnell sizes up the contents bottle, which is half-empty.

dialogues.speaker: PARNELL
dialogues.text: You fought this soldier by yourself. You've been drinking alone. I don't like that, Polly.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Drop the stone, counselor, You live in a glass house,

dialogues.speaker: PARNELL
dialogues.text: My windows were busted a long time ago so I can say as I please, When a man starts drinking alone he digs a hole for himself. Me -- I'm almost through to China.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Want an Italian cigar?

dialogues.speaker: PARNSLL
dialogues.text: No thanks. Those stink weeds are another sign of your decadence, Paul lights a cigar and returns to his play with the pian Parnell pours himself another drink.

dialogues.speaker: PARNELL
dialogues.text: {tossing the drink off). Polly, it's a fact. Since Mitch Lodwick beat you out of the office of prosecuting attorney you haven't been worth salt for peanuts... Not that I don't understand how you feel. Man gets beat for an office he's held a long time, he feels his community has deserted him -- the finger of scorn is pointed....

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: None but the lonely heart shall know my anguish, (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: O PARNELL
dialogues.text: It's been a full year since you were skinned at the polls, How long are you going to skulk like this?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: What the hell are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: PARNELL
dialogues.text: Man, you're an honest-to-God lawyer. You ought to make like one -- be here -- ready for clients -- not fishing or playing that rootity toot jazz --

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Go ahead, Parn, Have another drink, Don't stand on ceremony.

dialogues.speaker: PARNELL
dialogues.text: If it means keeping our friendship I guess I can take another wee drop. He pours a shot and downs it,

dialogues.speaker: . PAUL
dialogues.text: CO I'm making a living. I run some abstracts -- divorce Jane Doe from Jobn Doe once in a while == or threaten a few dead beats -- and in the evening I drink rye whiskey and read law with Parnell Emmett McCarthy -- one of the world's great men. There's a little silence,

dialogues.speaker: PARNELL
dialogues.text: That was a kind word, Polly. vo aes Sa pause) You know -- I might have been. That's. one reason I hate to see your talent pushed aside by lesser men. I look at you and see myself -- thirty years ago ~~ with the same love for the smell of the old brown books in a dusty office, (he takes-a book from a shelf) Now here's a rose, a lily, a sweet lupine -- the United States Supreme Court Reports! e Parnell takes out his specs, sits at the table. (CONTINUED)

She wears, everlastin flowered hat -- the badge of respectability among middle- western American women. dialogues.speaker: PAUL -

dialogues.speaker: PAUL

dialogues.speaker: MAIDA

dialogues.speaker: MAIDA
dialogues.text: Don't you want your toast? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turning preoccupied) I'll - I'll call you -- uh -- let you know how things go. He exits. Maida follows him into the hallway and calls af

dialogues.text: Don't let him pay you with Purple Hearts. Professional soldiers never have a dime. I know. I was married to one.

LAURA MAN is dressed in high heels, tight ankle length capri pants clinging jersey sweater. Her hair is smoothly brushed but Her eyes are still concealed behind dark glasses. She is idly against the fender of her parked car. On the lawn ab three-Storied, domed Courthouse the usual old men, foreve loitering on the Courthouse lawns, are silently watching 7) The sensuous woman is not in the least embarrassed by mouthed attention. Beyond the Courthouse and separated fr an alley is the county jail. Its barred windows overlook and street where Laura is waiting. Paul's car rolls up, n the curb. Paul gets out, sees Laura and the audience she gathered, After taking it all in for a moment he goes to is waiting.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I'm Paul Biegler,

dialogues.speaker: LAURA

dialogues.text: (continues; scooping the dog into her arms) This is Muff. Paul, a little embarrassed at the attention they are gett old men on the courthouse lawn, takes Laura's arm and the toward the jail,

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: You're tall.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (slightly os _ digsconcerted) I hope I haven't kept you waiting long.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Yes, I noticed, She chuckles -- an appealing, throaty laugh.

He speaks with a Finn

dialogues.text: eee  29 30

dialogues.text: Think that it would be alright if I talk to him in the Sheriff's office?

dialogues.text: Oh shu, Polly. You go in the Sheriff's office. I bring the soldier-boy down,

Along one side of the room a strai white line has been painted on the floor, running from wa On one wall at the end of the white line is a chart for t The barred windows of the room look out into the street a Courthouse lawn, Paul and Laura enter.

dialogues.text: More than that. You should see. All over. She smiles -- seems to be waiting for some reaction from

dialogues.speaker: MANION
dialogues.text: (looking at the white : line on the:floor). * I could walk it, I could walk it with a quart of red eye in my belly. Manion fastens his attention on the vision chart, He pace the chart to the opposite side of the room, reads it glib

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: ‘One thing, we can't claim your shooting Barney Quill was a case of mistaken identity. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Manion is not amused, He moves on to the bulletin board, big circular about the 10 most wanted,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Where're you from, Lieutenant?

dialogues.speaker: MANION
dialogues.text: Originally Pennsylvania. Where are you from?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Here, All my life,

dialogues.speaker: MANION
dialogues.text: The big ten. We've got the 10 best dressed dames, the 10 top tunes, the 10 top teams and now the 10 most wanted,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Don't knock it. It's the American dream, Those boys made the grade. Manion sits in a chair, takes out a carved ivory cigarett a package of cigarettes from his pocket, fits a cigarette holder and lights it with a gold pocket lighter,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (continues) Where'd you get the holder ?

dialogues.speaker: MANION
dialogues.text: Korea, It's hand carved, Ming Dynasty, 400 years old, .

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Clever people, the Chinese - smoking cigarettes in the sixteenth century.

dialogues.speaker: MANION
dialogues.text: (not blinking an eye) They did, you know. You were the D.A. around here, weren't you?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: For ten years,

dialogues.speaker: MANION
dialogues.text: What's your experience as a defense lawyer?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Not very much. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MANION
dialogues.text: How do I know you can handle my case?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I guess you don't know, Shall we talk about it?

dialogues.speaker: . MANION
dialogues.text: I suppose so,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Don't be so bored, Lieutenant, it's possible no lawyer can handle your case -- if you mean get you off scot- free,

dialogues.speaker: MANION
dialogues.text: (a flicker of 7 ee nothing else) I want a lawyer to defend me, Mr. Biegler -- not throw me to the wolves.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I'm giving you my first reaction to what I know about your case.

dialogues.speaker: MANION
dialogues.text: You're forgetting that Barney Quill raped my wife. I've got the unwritten law on my side,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (annoyed) Lieutenant Manion, the unwritten law is a myth, There is no such thing as the unwritten law and anyone who commits a murder on the theory that it does exist has just bought himself bed:and"board-in the State Penitentiary - maybe for life. With that in mind, perhaps we can proceed with a few questions and answers which may be some help to your defense, but probably won't, In the silence the two men measure each other. Paul calml Manion coldly considering, Paul takes out an Italian ciga

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (continues) May I borrow your lighter? Manion tosses the gold lighter, Paul lights his cigar, st (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: {continues) Nice, Sharply he tosses the lighter back to Manion. Manion puts away.

dialogues.speaker: _ MANION
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: How old are you?

dialogues.speaker: MANION
dialogues.text: Thirty-one.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: How long have you been in the service?

dialogues.speaker: MANION
dialogues.text: Since '50,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Have you seen action?

dialogues.speaker: MANION
dialogues.text: Plenty.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Decorations?

dialogues.speaker: MANION
dialogues.text: Plenty. Anybody who doesn't cut and run gets those -- like K~rations.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: How long were you in Korea? oe, MANION . I got there in-time for the big bug-out from the Yalu River.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Bug-out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Retreat.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: How old is your wife?

dialogues.speaker: MANION
dialogues.text: About my age. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: me PAUL O. . Is this your first marriage? :

dialogues.speaker: MANION
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: You're not on the witness stand. You don't have to answer yes or no. Just give me the matrimonial run down.

dialogues.speaker: MANION
dialogues.text: Is this necessary?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I'll be the judge of that,

dialogues.speaker: MANION
dialogues.text: C—O My first wife divorced me -- charged eruelty, eating crackers in bed... the usual stuff. Truth was, she found another guy while I was in Korea, I met Laura four years ago in Georgia. We were married after her divorce.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Did you know her husband?

dialogues.speaker: MANION
dialogues.text: He was in my outfit down there.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: You mean you were buddies? Manion draws on his cigarette and contemptuously looks aw

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (continues) 1 withdraw the questi I'm.a little ' .,old-fashioned, ~” lere- any children: by or from any of the marriages?

dialogues.speaker: MANION
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Any present prospects?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not unless Barney Quill started something. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: What kind of a gun did you. use on Quill?

dialogues.speaker: MANION
dialogues.text: War souvenir, Luger, The police have it now.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I guess you read the newspapers ? The stories about your case?

dialogues.speaker: . MANION
dialogues.text: Some of them,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Are they substantially correct? MANION ° .- wae Yes,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't see Barney Cuill rape or beat your wife? MANION . No. When she came to the trailer she told me what had happened,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: How long then before you went to Quill's place and killed him?

dialogues.speaker: MANION
dialogues.text: I don't know exactly. Maybe an hour. . PAUL’ That long, huh? The newspapers say your wife volunteered to take a lie-detector test. Do you know anything about this ?

dialogues.speaker: MANION
dialogues.text: Just what she's told me and what I've read,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Do you know how the lie-detector test turned out? (CON TINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MANION
dialogues.text: They didn't tell her, Sulo opens the door, looks in,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Yes, Sulo?

dialogues.speaker: SULO
dialogues.text: Polly, we got lunch served for the jail Would you like to eat with us, Polly?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Is your sister still cooking for the jail?

dialogues.speaker: SULO
dialogues.text: Oh, shu. She cooks,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Give her my compliments, Sulo. I won't be able to take lunch here today, I've a luncheon date downtown,

dialogues.speaker: MANION
dialogues.text: Nice going, Mr. Biegler.

dialogues.speaker: SULO
dialogues.text: (to Manion) Come on, bucko,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I'll be back after lunch,

dialogues.speaker: MANION
dialogues.text: (at the door) : =. Sorry if I offended you.a while ago.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: No, you're not. Manion smiles.a small'cool smile and follows Sulo.

dialogues.speaker: EXT, LAKE FRONT LUNCH STAND
dialogues.text: On the lake front of Iron City Paul and Parnell are at a counter, a plate of hard boiled eggs between them, each w bottle of beer, Here on the lake front are the great iron docks with the lake ships anchored alongside. The traffic sidewalk consists of workmen and sailors from the ships,

dialogues.speaker: PARNELL
dialogues.text: Pass the salt, Paul slides the salt along the counter to Parnell, Parnel his hard boiled egg,

dialogues.speaker: PARNELL
dialogues.text: Did you give the Lieutenant the well-known lecture?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: If you mean did I coach him into oe a phony story, no,

dialogues.speaker: PARNELL
dialogues.text: Maybe you're too pure, Paul, Too pure for the natural impurities of the law. Could be you owe the Lieutenant a chance to finda defense, Could also be you might guide him a little, show him the way and let him decide if he wants to take it, You want some salt?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (salting an egg) Anyway, I'm not the right lawyer for this man, He's insolent and he's hostile,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You-don't have ‘to ‘love him, just defend him, What's the matter, don't you need a fee? (a pause) You know something, Polly, I think you're a little bit afraid,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: A little bit afraid of what?

dialogues.speaker: PARNELL
dialogues.text: Afraid you might get licked, Paul sets about shelling another egg. A little time passe (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: a

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: There's only one thing more devious than a Philadelphia lawyer and that's an Irish lawyer, Pass the salt. Parnell hands over the salt shaker, smugly sets his teeth white meat of the hard boiled egg, DISSOLVE To:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul is waiting as Sulo ushers Manion in and closes the d has a wrapped package.under his arm, Manion glances coldl Paul, passes him and sits at the Sheriff's desk,

dialogues.speaker: MANION
dialogues.text: (in passing)... . -- Hello there, - eileen

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (with a smile) Tusually answer to the name of Paul,

dialogues.speaker: MANION
dialogues.text: Are we going to have some more jokes ?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Not unless you want to be the comic, Oh, here. Here're some cigarettes, He extends the wrapped package. Manion hesitates a moment then rather awkwardly accepts the package.

dialogues.speaker: MANION
dialogues.text: Thanks,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Peace?

dialogues.speaker: MANION
dialogues.text: Sure, (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Lieutenant, there are four ways I can defend murder. Number one: it wasn't murder - it was suicide or accidental, Number two: you didn't do it, Number three: you were legally justified - like self-defense or protection of your home. Number four: the killing was excusable.

dialogues.speaker: MANION
dialogues.text: Where do I fit into this rosy picture?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I'l, tell you where you don't fit. You don't fit in any of the first three.

dialogues.speaker: MANION
dialogues.text: Why wouldn't I be legally justified in killing the man who raped my wife?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: The time element. If you had caught him in the act the shooting might have been justified. But you didn't catch him and you had time to bring in the police. You didn't do that either. You're guilty of murder, premeditated and with vengeance. First degree murder in any court of law,

dialogues.speaker: MANION
dialogues.text: Ave you telling me to plead guilty?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: When I advise you to cop out you'll know it,

dialogues.speaker: MANION
dialogues.text: ‘Cop out? .

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Plead guilty and ask for mercy.

dialogues.speaker: MANION
dialogues.text: If you're not telling me to cop out, what are you telling me to do?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I'm not telling you to do anything. I want you to understand the letter of the law, (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MANION
dialogues.text: (a pause) Go on, .

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Go on to what?

dialogues.speaker: MANION
dialogues.text: To whatever it is you're getting at.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (with a tough little grin) You're very bright, Lieutenant. Now let's see how really bright you can be, Manion has been impressed and is now a little frightened. beads of sweat are on his forehead and his upper lip. a ve MANION I'm working at it.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Now because your wife was raped we'll have a favorable climate in the courtroom, You'll have sympathy with you -- if all the facts are true. All you'll need is a legal peg which will let the jury hang up their sympathy in your behalf. Do you follow me? Manion nods.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (continues) — What's your legal excuse, Lieutenant -Manion - your legal éxcuse. for. killing ‘Barney Quill? © °° , :

dialogues.speaker: MANION
dialogues.text: Not justification.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: No, not justification.

dialogues.speaker: MANION
dialogues.text: Excuse---just an excuse.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Manion, hands trembling a little, takes out his ivory hol cigarette, He becomes annoyed at his shaking hands, angri the holder and the cigarette on the Sheriff's desk. He ri away nervously. :

dialogues.speaker: MANION
dialogues.text: What excuses are there?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: How should I know? You're the one who plugged Quill, With his thumb Manion wipes the perspiration from his upp Almost unaware of his physical movement, he balances on t white line on the floor, walking it carefully, as if it w His jaw is knotted, his mind desperately churning his pro He goes to the, window and stares out, lips moving a litt to himself, Paul is leaning against the wall, poker-faced hooded, watching Manion,

dialogues.speaker: MANION
dialogues.text: (whispering) I must've been mad,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: MANION
dialogues.text: I said Iwas mad,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: A bad temper is no excuse,

dialogues.speaker: MANION
dialogues.text: Imean -- I mean, I must've been crazy. (a long pause) Am I getting warmer? Paul puts on his hat, goes to the door and opens it,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (calling) Okay, Sulo.

dialogues.speaker: MANION
dialogues.text: (turning to Paul) Paul? Am I getting warmer?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (at the door) I'll tell you that after I've talked to your wife, In the meantime see if you can remember just how crazy you were, — DISSOLVE To:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Paul enters, Maida is banging efficiently on her typew the respectable flowered hat on her head. Paul's office d is closed but MUSIC filters through. Maida, without break the typewriter's rhythm, jerks her head toward Paul's off door,

dialogues.speaker: MAIDA
dialogues.text: Mrs, Manion's been waiting a long time. She's gone through your albums from Dixieland to Brubeck,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: What do you think of her?

dialogues.speaker: MAIDA
dialogues.text: (thinking a moment) Soft--easy--the kind men like to abuse -- and do. Did you get some money?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (considering what Maida has said about Laura) . What? Oh, no. I haven't decided to take the case yet. {he starts for his door and stops) You surprise me sometimes.

dialogues.speaker: MAIDA
dialogues.text: (going back to her work) Why? I've been around, Paul smiles his appreciation of Maida and enters hig offi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul enters, closing the door behind him, His record play working at some lively MUSIC. Laura, wearing her dark gla and with the little dog cuddled against her side, is stre on the old couch.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Hi, : He goes to the record player, shuts it off. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cd

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I hope you don't mind, but I think we'd better talk, Laura sits up on the couch,’ one leg curled under.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: You're a funny kind of a lawyer. The music, I mean,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Aren't lawyers supposed to like music?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Well, not that kind of music.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: E guess that settles it then == I'm a funny kind of a lawyer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He goes to his desk and searches through drawers and cubb for a possible cigarette, -

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (continues; as he searches) Where's your home, Mrs. Manion? That is, where did you go to school -- live -- when you were growing up?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: No place in particular, We sort of moved around. My father was a boomer. You know, a construction boomer? Building dams mostly. : You can call me Laura.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL,
dialogues.text: (still searching) Are your people alive, Laura?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Ihave some cigarettes in here somewhere,

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: (opening her purse) Do you want a cigarette? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: CO No, I was going to offer you one.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: (putting a cigarette in her mouth) Well, you could light it for me.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Certainly. He fumbles in his pockets for a match, can't seem to find

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: {extending a gold lighter) Here, He strikes the lighter, lights her cigarette and then exa golden object.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: It's exactly like your husband's,

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: (taking the lighter) Yes, he gave me this one because I liked the one he had, He's like that, He gives me presents all the time, q

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: You have a happy marriage ?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: (a little beat - a little diversion with her purse)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: What went wrong with your first marriage?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Well, what went wrong is when I went for Manny.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: That's honest enough,

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: But it was more than just that, (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: LAURA (cont'd) Like I told you, I grew up on the move and Jack -- that was my first husband -- Jack didn't like to move. He wouldn't even take a transfer when he had the chance, I was really bored, Manny likes to go. We're always going, whenever we get a chance, We've been allover, I'm thirsty,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Water, or would a beer do?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: I think a beer would do fine. Paul goes into the kitchen, cpens the icebox, returns wit of beer anda glass. _She sits cross~legged -- Indian fash on the couch,

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: (continuing) Aren't you having one?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: No, not now,

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Could Muff have a little? In that ashtray maybe. He loves beer. Paul looks askance but pours some beer into an ashtray, p the floor, The dog leaps down and hungrily laps up the be

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: (continues; watching the dog) He's sweet, toate he? He'll goto sleep now. . Paul studies Laura as she watches the dog, wondering if s truly ingenuous, He hands her a glass of beer. Laura sips beer, With her full, soft lips against the rim of the gla smiles at Paul.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: (continuing) You married?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: No. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: That's nice, What do you do with this big house if you aren't married?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: It's the family home. I'm the last of the family,

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: I bet it has lots of bedrooms,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: A few. How about it? Are you ready? She rolls beer glass against her cheek ~ lips lifted in t disconcerting smile,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (continues) I mean are you ready to tell me the story? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LAURA.
dialogues.text: I know what you mean,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Suppose you tell me everything you told the State Police -- plus everything you didn't tell the State Police. There is a moment's wait. Laura's smile goes away but the returns,

dialogues.speaker: LA
dialogues.text: Where shall I begin?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: What time did you go to Quill's bar?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Right after dinner -- about eight- thirty, I guess. Manny was late getting home from the firing range. We had dinner, then he lay down and went to sleep. I hadn't been out of . the trailer almost all day, so I took Muff and a flashlight and walked over to the bar, I bought a drink and Played the pinball machine,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Many people in the bar?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Not many. Barney came over and challenged me to a game, For drinks. You know,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: How well did you know Barney?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Well, he owned this bar where Manny and I went sometimes. That's .

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Had he ever made a pass at you?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: No, nothing like that at all.

dialogues.speaker: . PAUL
dialogues.text: Was he drinking heavily that night ? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: O LAURA .
dialogues.text: He didn't seem to be, at least not while we were playing pinball.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Were you with him all the time you were there?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: No, there were other people playing too.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: What time did you leave the bar?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: About eleven. I left by the side door and Muff was carrying the flashlight. He carries the flashlight in his mouth. He's so cute, running along ahead with the light shining.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (glancing at the now sleeping dog) Was he sober?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Muff? Of course he was sober. Oh, you're joking, aren't you?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (dlatly) Yes I'm joking. Go ahead,

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Barney came from somewhere, not from the door I left by, and said. vhe ‘was going my way and’he: could. . drive me home. He said the bears had been prowling around that night and I oughtn't to walk home. Bears come out of the woods sometimes to scavenge.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Harmless enough, aren't they?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Yes. I guess I wouldn't have been afraid in the daylight, but... you know, e ' the dark isn't the same, (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: oo

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Iknow. So you got in Barney's car,

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: I got in and he drove straight to the trailer park,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: He made overtures?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: No, nothing. When we got to the trailer park the auto gate was closed, Mr. Lemon always locks the gate around eleven or a little after, I thanked Barney and started to get out of the car, but he said there wasn't any need for me to walk, that he could drive me into the park on another road, I didn't know there was another road, but in he drove on even before I could say ~ ~ yes or no,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Were you alarmed?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: No, I'm not usually afraid of men, And anyway, he hadn't touched me or even said anything out of the way.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Don't women sort of instinctively know when a man's on the make?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Yes, but that's only usual with me - with men, I mean - almost all men,’ Ever since I was a kid, You, for instance, You're interested, But there isn't any reason to be afraid of you and it was like that with Barney.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Mrs. Manion, believe me, I'm not in the least...

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Call me Laura, (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: O PAUL
dialogues.text: Laura, I'm only interested in helping your husband -~- nothing else,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I don't mean you'd try anything, I just mean, it's the way you look at me,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: It would be pretty difficult not to look at you.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Oh, you mean the way I dress? You don't like it?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I love it, honey, dearly love it. Now let's keep moving. How were you dressed that night?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: A sweater, like this, and a skirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: oO And the rest?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Underneath? I had ona slip, panties and a bra. .

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: No girdle?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: No, I don't need a girdle. Do you think I need a girdle?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I'm not your couturier, Laura. I'm concerned with facts which might be of use to me -- or to the prosecuting attorney. “LAURA . Well, I don't wear one.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (gently, exasperated) . Please go on with what happened.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Well, he turned off the highway into a lane in the woods and stopped the car and turned off the lights. He grabbed me and said, "I'm going to rape you." Just like that.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: He used those words?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Exactly those words, Muff began to bark and he threw him out the window, I could hear Muff whining outside the car -- all through it. Barney began to try to get at me, and I fought him as best Icould. He was terribly strong,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: . . . Did you cry out? Did you scream?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: It didn't seem any use there in the woods, He began to shout names at me - like, 'army slut' and some other names - and then he drew back and hit me with his fist. He hit me again and I didn’t fight any more, I think I was only half conscious, but I know that he tore my panties off - and did what he wanted,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: The newspaper said a doctor examined you and didn't think you'd been raped,

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: I don't care what the doctor thought ~ a@ woman doesn't, mistake these things,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: All right. Go ahead,

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: (telling it calmly) I don't know exactly what happened. then, I must've fainted, because the next thing I remember the car was moving. Barney was driving very fast, and he was breathing hard, almost gasping. An ugly, awful sound, (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: LAURA (cont'd) We were on the main road to the trailer park and he swung in by the gate and stopped, I opened the door and Muff jumped out first, with the lighted flashlight in his mouth,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Wait a minute, I thought you said he had thrown Muff out of the car in the woods,

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: He did, But Muff was in the car when we got to the gate, He must have let Muff back in, I don't remember,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Goon, You opened the door and Muff jumped out first,

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Before I could get out Barney grabbed me and said he was going to tear all my clothes off and attack me again, I got away and ran. I could see Muff at an opening in the fence. He was scooting back and forth with the flashlight, Barney caught me from behind and I fell to the ground. He fell on top of me and started to beat me again with his fists. I thought he was going to kill me. I screamed and somehow I got on my feet again and ran toward the fence, I went through the opening in the fence and followed Muff who was running along ahead with the flashlight. I kept following the light and he led me to ! our trailer, °

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: You didn't see Barney again?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Inever laid eyes on him again -- dead or alive,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I guess that's enough for now, Laura, (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: I've got lots of time -- all you want.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Where can I reach you?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: I'm still in Thunder Bay but I'll drive down again in the morning.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Fine. He goes to the door to open it. Laura picks up Muff but r on the couch stroking the dog. .

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (continues) Was there something else?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: (after a moment) No. She comes reluctantly to the door as Paul opens it,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Tomorrow. Laura goes into Maida's office. Paul, from his office, wa her with circumspection.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: (stops at Maida's desk) Thanks for letting me play the records,

dialogues.speaker: MAIDA
dialogues.text: You're very welcome;

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Thanks alot. 'Bye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She goes on into the hallway as Parnell is entering. He l pass, looks after her and comes into Maida's office, Paul has gone ta his closet, gets out his fishing hat, selects lures, pins them on the hat.

dialogues.speaker: PARNELL
dialogues.text: (to Maida) - Who was that? MAIDA. The lady in the case, (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Parnell whistles his surprise, comes into Paul's office a dismay watches Paul gathering the fishing gear. Maida, at desk, listens to their conversation,

dialogues.speaker: PARNELL
dialogues.text: I guess you're not going to take the case, huh?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I don't know. Depends on what Manion has to tell me tomorrow. He's thinking things out.

dialogues.speaker: PARNELL
dialogues.text: (pleased) Oh -- well --

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: If I take it I want you in it.

dialogues.speaker: PARNELL
dialogues.text: Me? -- ina big murder case? Why, boy, the sight of this whiskey drinking old man at the counsel table would ruin you.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Ineed you.

dialogues.speaker: PARNELL
dialogues.text: You mean that?

dialogues.speaker: MAIDA
dialogues.text: Why else would he say it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be glad to work with you outside the courtroom, but not in the courtroom, Polly.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Suit yourself about that. But either way, I'll have to be able to depend on you. Will you lay off the booze?

dialogues.speaker: PARNELL
dialogues.text: (crestfallen) Oh. I don't know about that, Polly. -- I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: MAIDA
dialogues.text: Why don't you know? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PARNELL
dialogues.text: Do you think I could -- lay off the booze?

dialogues.speaker: MAIDA
dialogues.text: Ever tried it? Parnell's silence is in the negative.

dialogues.speaker: MAIDA
dialogues.text: (continues) Try it.

dialogues.speaker: PARNELL
dialogues.text: (a long pause) I've never been in a big murder case -- not once in all my life.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Up to you, Parn. Paul, with his fishing gear passes Parnell, goes into the office, turns back,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (continues) Be around tonight?

dialogues.speaker: PARNELL
dialogues.text: (preoccupied with the idea of a big murder case) Yeah -~ yeah, I'll be around, Paul exits. Parnell goes into Maida's office, slowly sits chair,

dialogues.speaker: PARNELL
dialogues.text: (continues) You. know, Maida-darling, I might manage it. I might manage to be a real lawyer again -- for a little while anyway. FADE OUT.

dialogues.speaker: INT, SHERIFF'S OFFICE
dialogues.text: Manion, brows knitted, is working at his defense. Paul, s an Italian cigar, quietly listens. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MANION
dialogues.text: ++» I blacked out. I mean, after we talked yesterday, I went back over the whole thing in my mind, You see, I hadn't done that before -- I was trying to forget about it, But when I tried remembering it, there were some pieces missing. I remember going to the bar with a gun, I remember Quill's face behind the bar -- but I don't seem to remember anything else, not even going home,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Don't you remember firing your gun? Five shots are a lot of noise to forget. MANION . ¥e. hey— —————- didn't seem to be connected with me -- like they were far away, like somebody else was doing the shooting, Manion mops his face with a handkerchief, nervously fits cigarette into his holder. Paul waits for a moment or two PAUL . Lieutenant Manion, I'll take your case.

dialogues.speaker: MANION
dialogues.text: (in great relief) Thanks, Thanks, Mr. Biegler.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Now there's the matter of a fee. Three thousand. That's reasonable enough, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: MANION
dialogues.text: Sure -- sure, more than reasonable.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: When can you pay?

dialogues.speaker: MANION
dialogues.text: It'll have to be later, Right now I'm broke,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: You're what? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MANION
dialogues.text: Broke -~ busted -- flat. I haven't got three bucks, much less three thousand.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Well, can you raise it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Not until I get out of jail, but payday is next week. I can give you a hundred fifty on account. If you get me off I'll give you a promissory note for the rest.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Suppose you're convicted?

dialogues.speaker: MANION
dialogues.text: That's a calculated risk, isn't it? -- for both of us.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Suppose I don't go along with you unless you pay me half of the fee?

dialogues.speaker: MANION
dialogues.text: (an amused glint) I'd have to take a lawyer the Court would appoint. I've got my defense now, haven't 1? -- Insanity?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: You know, I think I'll just stay with you, to make damned sure you get off.

dialogues.speaker: MANION
dialogues.text: You won't lose anything by it.

dialogues.speaker: . PAUL
dialogues.text: All right. It's a deal, I'll take the one-fifty and a promissory note when and if you're cleared.

dialogues.speaker: MANION
dialogues.text: Thanks.  Where.do we start? You'll have to tell me. Remember, I've been kind of nuts and I'm just recovering my wits. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Your wits will do nicely, Lieutenant. We're going to need a psychiatrist and since neither of us has much money, do you think the army would stir one up for you? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MANION
dialogues.text: I know a colonel in the Pentagon, I'll write a letter,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: You do that. Okay, I'll get back to you, Paul goes to the door,

dialogues.speaker: MANION
dialogues.text: What will you do now?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL -
dialogues.text: See your wife again, for one thing.

dialogues.speaker: MANION
dialogues.text: (an odd pause) Why? Didn't you see her yesterday? The curious change in Manion's attitude registers with Pa

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: That's right, Idid. She's a pretty woman = your wife.

dialogues.speaker: MANION
dialogues.text: (trying tobe — casual) ' A man gets used to the way his wife looks.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Yeah, I guess he does, (opens the door) Okay, Sulo, . (to Manion) See you. Paul.exits, Manion stands very still, ‘his face drawn int

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul comes from the jail, pauses, thinking it over, puzzl disturbing scene he's had with Manion, He moves on throug alleyway between the jail and courthouse, enters the rear courthouse. |

dialogues.speaker: INT, CORRIDOR
dialogues.text: Paul appears around the corner of the marble alleyway, co to a door which is labeled, OFFICE OF PROSECUTING ATTORNE ~~ enters the office,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A couple of secretaries are at work at their typewriters. to Mitch's private office is open and MITCH is at his des Paul enters the outer office, Mitch spies him,

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: (booming) Come on in, Polly! Come on in! Paul pushes through the office gate and goes into Mitch's office, The office is quite handsomely decorated with pri modern artists, new, modernistic furniture and vertical v blinds,

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: , (continues) You haven't been in here since you vacated, have you Polly? Don't recognize the old place, huh? My wife did it for me -- she's a graduate decorator, Smart girl, very smart girl. Look at this, real genuine Van Gogh prints -- and here, here, try this chair. It sort of does things. He pushes Paul into a large contour chair. The moment Pau the back drops down, the footrest leaps up and the chair massage. Paul endures the operation with slightly alarmed patience, lying helplessly, shaking uncomfortably.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: (continues) Great, isn't it? Good for the nerves they say.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (jiggling) . How do you shut it off? Mitch presses a button, The chair stops wiggling, snaps P into an ‘upright position; the footrest drops and‘his. fe floor, : :

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: There we are, Feel better?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (getting out of the chair) I feel all shook up, Mitch, I just stopped by to tell you I've got both feet in the Manion case.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: You're going to cop out, aren't you? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: No,

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: That's a mistake, Polly, It's open and shut,

dialogues.speaker: . PAUL
dialogues.text: Maybe. We'll see.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Judge Maitland is still in the hospital, Maybe you'd like to agree toa continuance until he gets back, If we go with the case now, we'll have to try before some grab-bag judge they'll send in, Me, I'd rather have Maitland,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: So would I -= but that would also mean my client would have to lie in jail for another two or three months before the trial, Now if you drop the charge down to manslaughter so I can get him out on bail, we'll agree to a continuance.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: You wouldn't do that if you were D, A, You wouldn't drop a charge from life down to a fifteen year maximum penalty.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I might... since a big fat lie-detector test on his wife gave the truth to the rape story, He'll have the jury with him, .

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: (into the trap) How:did you know ==

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stops suddenly, Paul grins,

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: (continues) Bit, didn'tI? Well, anyway, the result of a lie~detector test isn't admissable evidence == you can't use it.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: No, but it carries moral weight. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: i

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: What are you going to use for a defense ~ old box tops?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I'll think of something, (he turns at the door) I wouldn't sit in that chair much, Mitch <= it could shake a man's brain loose, He exits.

dialogues.speaker: EXT, COURTHOUSE
dialogues.text: Paul comes from the courthouse down the steps and is gree Laura's dog. Muff comes romping across the lawn to meet h Laura not far behind, Laura is dressed in tight Western s and boots, Her blouse is Navajo with the laces open, reve the push of her ample bosom, With open-mouthed attention, eternal loiterers are following Laura's progress across t Muff bounds into Paul's arms, ‘LAURA (arriving) He remembers you, Paul -= he likes you,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: He likes the beer in my icebox, (conscious again of the attention ‘ they're getting) What's the occasion today -= a buffalo hunt?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: (childishly turning for inspection) I got them in Arizona when we were stationed there, Aren't they smart -- I think they're very smart,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (avoiding) We can sit in my car <= over here, Carrying the dog, he leads Laura across the lawn to the p area by the jail,

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He opens the door for her and goes around to sit under th On the driver's side of Paul's car is the handle to a spo which is just outside the windshield, The spotlight is ba -by a rear-view mirror, As the scene proceeds, Paul casua turns the handle, moving the mirror until it is trained u jail, Inthe mirror, Paul can see Manion's cell window -- Manion is there watching,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Couple of things have occurred to me. The undergarments which Barney tore off -- who has them now? -- the police?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: You mean my panties?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: All right, your panties,

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: I haven't seen them since. We gave the torn skirt and sweater to the police and I went with the police up that lane into the woods but we couldn't find anything except my glasses,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Your glasses? You don't mean you were wearing glasses all through that.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: They were in a case in my hand, I use them to read or play pinball -- things like that, I guess I tried to get out of the car and dropped them.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: ‘You!ll be interested'te know your lie-deteéctor test came out in your favor,

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Of course it did. I could've told you it would,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: You weren't worried about it?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: (laying her hand on his arm) No, why should I be?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: “™ Would you like to have something to OD worry about?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Silly,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Like your husband watching us from his cell window, Laura jerks her hand away from his arm as if it had been almost cowers in the corner, Shaken, she takes off her da and covers her eyes for a moment with her hand,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (continues) All right, Let's have it,

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: (murmuring) : Did he.say something to you?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Just enough. Are you afraid of him?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: (murmuring) oO Yes.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Is that the reason you volunteered for a lie-detector test -- for him?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Yes,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I'll tell him how the test turned out.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: {putting on her dark glasses) You're very kind, you really are, Paul,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Does he have reason to be jealous?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Even before we were married he was jealous, (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: LAURA (cont'd) I should've known how it would be. But it's funny -- he likes to show me off, likes me to dress the way I dress, but then he's furious if a man pays attention to me. I've tried to leave him, but I can't -- he begs and I give in,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: If you think I've forgotten my question, I haven't.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: (regaining her smile) Ihave,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I'V. ask it again. Does he have any reason to be jealous?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: (she seems to be measuring Paul from behind the dark glasses) No. Not once -- not ever. The SHOT GOES OUT on Paul's probing, calculating gaze. FADE OUT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul's dusty car speeds along the lovely, wild lake shore

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maida is ‘in the back seat. Paul is driving, with Parnell beside him. Parnell is pale and perspiring, touching his now and then with a handkerchief which he holds wadded in palm, In his other hand he holds a half empty bottle of r Pop.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: The one thing that can bust this case open is Manion's jealousy. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PARNELL
dialogues.text: Let's thank our little apples we have O Lodwick on the other side, He'll never tumble to it,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Maybe, (glances at Parnell) I shouldn't have asked you to lay off the booze,

dialogues.speaker: PARNELL
dialogues.text: I'll do it if it kills me,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: : You look like it might. Parnell takes a swig of the soda, makes a face.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (continues) At least let me get you a beer instead of that strawberry pop.

dialogues.speaker: PARNELL
dialogues.text: Strawberry pop reminds me of a better day in my life, Strawberry pop in a bucket of ice with a picnic basket by the lake and my pretty Nora still alive. No, no beer, I'll stick with this,

dialogues.speaker: MAIDA
dialogues.text: Will someone tell me why I was commandeered for this junket to ' Thunder Bay? q.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: You're going to get a manicure in the beauty parlor and gather all the gossip you can about the deceased Barney Quill,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: We've got to sell the jury on Mrs, Manion's rape story. A lot of it will depend on what kind of man Quill was, That's what we're going to find out, if we can. They drive on,

dialogues.speaker: EXT, STREET IN THUNDER BAY
dialogues.text: A winding, rambling street on the lake shore -- busy now, winter most of it will be shuttered, Thunder Bay is that MUSIC blares from the bingo parlor -- a sporting store wi fishing tackle on the sidewalk engages the rapt attention fishermen -- testing rods, tinkering with reels. Children suits run across the street without regard for traffic -- pokes along -- plump matrons in shorts at the hot dog sta occasional slim, blossoming girl in a bathing suit -- men ducks and sun visors == soldiers off duty, Most of the mo to and from the lake where rowboats drift about in the su ' cast from the piers and swimmers dive from the floats, comes slowly on the street, draws up to the curb by a sig advertises -- BRIGITTE'S BEAUTY SHOPPE, The car door open and Maida steps to the sidewalk,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Meet me for lunch at Barney's inn... down at the end of the street,

dialogues.speaker: MAIDA
dialogues.text: Right, She closes the rear door, moves away toward the beauty sh enters, The front car door opens and Parnell bumbles out,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: PARNELL
dialogues.text: I'm going to tool around the taverns in search of truth,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Maybe you'd better stay with me.

dialogues.speaker: PARNELL
dialogues.text: Trust me, lad = trust me, I'll arrive at the inn loaded with nothing more than strawberry pop. He closes the car-door, adjusts his hat at a rakish angle down the street. Paul drives away.

dialogues.speaker: EXT, THUNDER BAY INN
dialogues.text: A large, three-story frame structure with a fresh coat of screened~in verandas, its lawn shaded by elderly trees. I well-kept relic from the turn of the century when Thunder more graceful resort, Outside the hotel are parked numero and tourists come and go from the main entrance, (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: An unlighted neon-sign identifies ‘THE THUNDER BAY INN" and in smaller script advertises, “Breakfast, Lunch and D and in block letters, ''Cocktails.'' The bar room has a s entrance and is labeled by an unlighted neon-sign as the Its door is closed and the windows shuttered with venetia Paul drives up and finds a parking space near the entranc bar. He gets out of the car and scans the front of the ho going to the door of the bar room. On the closed door a s "OPEN 5 p.m." Paul pushes the door, finds it mlocked, ent

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like all bars concerned with evening business, the aftern atmosphere is cool, pleasant and restful. It is darkened, for back-bar lights and sunlight filtering from around th venetian blinds, It is at the moment completely deserted. bartender has been at work, preparing the bar for its eve business. A collection of empty bottles are on one end of the glassware is covered by white cloths and a can of bar is on the bar with a polishing rag. At one end of the bar couple of pinball machines -- near the door, Chairs are s on the tables and in the booths. Behind the bar one secti the bar mirror is devoted to a display of gold and silver cups and a collection of enlarged snapshots, mainly showi broad-chested, curly haired man of about fifty. Some of t pictures include other people, but always the curly haire is prominent -~ holding a prize angling catch -- with a r his hand and a dead buck on the fender of his car -- with pistol raised and posed -- and several other pictures of man, probably made when he was in his twenties, wearing b gloves and in fighting pose. One of the most recent snaps presents the man stripped to the waist, posed with a doub axe above a neatly severed log. Beyond the bar a short fl of steps leads up to a closed door above which a sign rea "TO LOBBY." . Paul, upon entering the room from the outside, pauses unt eyes become accustomed to the darkness, glances. about, f the:plunger‘on. one of. the pinball machines; moves..on't His attention is attracted by the display of photographs cups. He moves around behind the bar, picks up a gold cup reads its inscription, replaces it, examines another, His goes to the snapshots and he puts on his glasses for a fi of the pictures. From his POV the CAMERA CLOSES IN and MOVES from picture to picture. Now in turning to come fro behind the bar, he notices a narrow shelf built up under of the bar. He stoops, looks into the shelf, finds it emp .Puazling with the contraption he tentatively slips his h the narrow space and suddenly withdraws the hand, finger thumb cocked to represent a pistol, He looks down the len the bar and sees two more shelves of like character, one center by the space reserved for waiter's service and the at the far end, . (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: ~*~ He starts to move along back of the bar toward these OC but the lobby door opens, There in the doorway is a sm , hard-faced man with black, inscrutable eyes, This is PA

dialogues.speaker: PAQUETTE
dialogues.text: All right? -- You like it -back there all right?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I was looking at these pictures. This was Barney Quill, wasn't it?

dialogues.speaker: PAQUETTE
dialogues.text: That's right -- Barney Quill,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: My name's Paul Biegler, I'm --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ——-... PAQUETTE I know who you are. I've seen you around Iron City,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: You didn't tell me your name, did you?

dialogues.speaker: PAQUETTE
dialogues.text: Paquette. a Paquette takes up the polish and the rag, goes to work on surface. Paul moves around and sits on a stool,

dialogues.speaker: PAQUETTE
dialogues.text: (continues) We don't open until five o'clock,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Ican wait. I haven't got the shakes yet. You were on the job that night, weren't you -- the night Barney was

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: “killed? ‘ PAQUETTE Like the newspaper said, I was present,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: You're the one who stopped Lieutenant Manion outside, aren't you?

dialogues.speaker: PAQUETTE
dialogues.text: That's right. He pointed the gun at me and said, 'You want some tao, oe Buster?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cd

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: And you said 'no' because your name isn't Buster.

dialogues.speaker: PAQUETTE
dialogues.text: There wasn't anything funny about it, Mr. Biegler,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL. _
dialogues.text: Sorry. I'm afflicted with a sense of humor. Where were you when Barney was killed, Mr. Paquette? Paquette doesn't answer, industriously works at his polis

dialogues.speaker: PAQUETTE

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (looking at the photographs) Barney was kind of a rough character, wasn't he? -- ex-prize fighter, muscle man, fancy with guns.

dialogues.speaker: , PAQUETTE

dialogues.speaker: PAQUETTE

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Barney's wife? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: qd:

dialogues.text: He didn't have a wife. Mary was -- his manager,

dialogues.speaker: PAQUETTE
dialogues.text: Mary, I guess,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Mary again, huh?

dialogues.speaker: PAQUETTE
dialogues.text: What's the matter with that?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: You mean, what's the matter with Mary? I don't know what's the matter with Mary. Mary what?

dialogues.speaker: PAQUETTE
dialogues.text: Pilant -- Mary Pilant.

She is dressed ina simple sum dress, She's in her twenties -- a fresh, pleasant face, s handsome figure. . dialogues.text: Do you know Lieutenant Manion's wife?

dialogues.speaker: . .- SERGEANT
dialogues.text: Sure, Know the Lieutenant, too. He's a good officer, She's all right, too -~ friendly =- a good kid, A CORPORAL at the table makes a nasty little chuckle,

dialogues.text: Oh, Tell me ~ who!s this "babe! at the hotel? (CONTINUED)

The lobby is thriving and a group of guests ar by the closed door to the dining room, waiting for the lu to arrive, Paulis among them, The double dining room door swung open by a waitress and guests file into the dining spacious, cool place which includes part of the screened and overlooks the lake. Behind Mary is Paquette, nodding whispering, seeming to say, ''That's him." Mary lets the close over her face. Maida enters, spies Paul, wends her through the tables to the veranda. dialogues.text: How was the manicure? ‘ MAIDA Ask me any question about anybody. I've got all the dope.

dialogues.text: Can you tell me about 2a woman named Mary Pilant?

dialogues.speaker: MAIDA
dialogues.text: Easy. Mary Pilant may or may not have been the mistress of the late B. Quill. The manicurists are in favor of the mistress theory and the hair stylists are agin it. But all agree some kind of hanky-panky was going on here. (she sees Mary approaching the table) To be continued.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: . (extending a:meny) A menu? .

dialogues.speaker: . MAIDA
dialogues.text: Thank you. Mary moves on. Maida, glancing after her, turns back to P sees that he too, is watching after Mary.

dialogues.speaker: MAIDA
dialogues.text: (continues) Pretty, huh?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Very pretty. .Go ahead. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MAIDA
dialogues.text: There is one story which says that Barney's wild night with Mrs. Manion was somehow triggered by Mary Pilant --. seems she had been stepping out with a soldier and Barney blew his stack, got tanked up and exploded,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Who is this Pilant -- local?

dialogues.speaker: MAIDA
dialogues.text: No, a Canadian, Barney brought her in to dress up this place and she stayed to manage for him, I'd say she's done all right.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Better than all right -- she's in for the estate. om MAIDA - She doesn't look like a bad sort, does she? Looks sweet.

The pretty one with the menus, Paul stares at Maida almost shocked, Astonished, he looks door where Mary is standing, Mary is watching his table. meet and she turns away to greet Parnell who has at this arrived at the dining room entrance. Parnell gestures tow table-and Mary leads the way to the table,

dialogues.speaker: . PAUL

dialogues.text: (glancing at the empty dining room door} Yes, I can take a minute. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.text: Parnell draws a chair out for Mary and then seats himeelf

dialogues.speaker: PAUL

dialogues.text: A very nice man,

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I don't know what happened with Lieutenant Manion's wife, so there really isn't anything for me to explain, is there? , Guests appear in the dining room doorway and Mary rises.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: (continues) Would you pardon me? The waitress will take your order when you're ready. So nice to have met you -- Mr. Biegler -- Mr. McCarthy~-Mrs. Rutledge. She moves away.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Lo (looking after Mary) Parn, what did you get on Quill?

dialogues.speaker: PARNELL
dialogues.text: Nothing we could turn into evidence. Nothing that would make anybody believe he was a rapist. A WAITRESS comes to the table, says "Orders please," and three companions consult their menus.

dialogues.speaker: INT, THUNDER BAY INN
dialogues.text: Paul, followed by Maida and Parnell, enters from the dini Paul goes to the hotel desk where a CLERK -- a plain, har man ~- is working at an adding machine,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I beg your pardon,

dialogues.speaker: . CLERK
dialogues.text: Yessir?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I'm Paul Biegler, attorney at law. I represent the soldier who shot Mr. Quill, I was just wondering -- did you happen to be on duty that night ?

dialogues.speaker: CLERK
dialogues.text: Why yes sir, as a matter of fact I was... The Clerk's attention is drawn away from Paul to Mary Pil is standing in the dining room door, She gives a minute n shake of her head. Paul turns to follow the Clerk's gaze turns back to the Clerk,

dialogues.speaker: CLERK
dialogues.text: Sorry, I like my job, Mr. Biegler. Paul nods, understanding that Mary has silenced the Clerk goes toward the main exit, pauses as he comes abreast of Parnell and Maida beside him. .

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Your loyalty.to the dead Mr. Quill is very touching, Miss Pilant,

dialogues.speaker: . MARY
dialogues.text: Barney was well liked here, by everyone, Mr. Biegler. ao PAUL . Very generous of everyone to overlook hie little faults -- like raping other men's wives. Mary colors -- tears spring instantly into her eyes. Abru walks away.

dialogues.speaker: PARNELL
dialogues.text: If she could have helped you've sure fixed that wagon now.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: It was already fixed. What I don't understand is why. Why don't they want to part with some simple, honest information about Barney Quill and his character?

In a finely coordinated movement, Manion rises, reaches t the bars, catches Miller's hair, jerks Miller down and ag the bars, Miller YELLS in pain, wrenches away, falling ba across his cot, Fast steps on the iron stairs and Sulo ap from below.

dialogues.text: Me, dummy. [hit my shin.on this lousy iron cot, . (CONTINUED)

Laura's eyes grow large and hurt, tears well up and’she t

dialogues.text: (after a careful study of the people before him) For those of you I haven't met, my name is Weaver. I'm from downstate and I'm sitting temporarily while your good Judge Maitland is recovering from a severe illness, There's no need to dwell at length upon my methods. One judge is much like another, The only differences may be in the state of their digestions or their proclivities for sleeping on the bench. For myself, Ican digest pig iron, and while I might appear to doze occasionally, you'll find that I keep ore éye open for tricky lawyers, ee

dialogues.speaker: . JUDGE WEAVER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

PARN, LISTEN TO * THIS 'BUT'.,. ‘but the fact that one accused of committing a crime may have been able to comprehend the nature and consequence of this act and to know that it was wrong, nevertheless’ ...!

dialogues.text: (takes:a swig of — : Strawberry soda) By the saints, this strawberry soda pop is beginning to taste like good rye whiskey!

Why don't we get together and informally agree to ask his honor for an adjournment -- just for a day or so, and let our doctor visit with the defendant. dialogues.text: -. DANCER’ OQ There's really no need for our doctor to examine your client. Naturally I was only following the usual procedure,

dialogues.text: (whispering) I think you're a shyster, Mr. Biegler. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (whispering) You've unmasked me, Lieutenant, While this exchange between Parnell, Manion and Paul has on, in the b,g. a new witness, one LLOYD BURKE has been c and sworn. Now Mitch takes up the examination of Lloyd Bu

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Mr. Burke, will you state your profession please?

dialogues.speaker: BURKE
dialogues.text: I'm a commercial photographer.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Were you called upon by the police to take photographs of the body of the deceased Bernard Quill before he was removed from the scene of death?

dialogues.speaker: BURKE
dialogues.text: Yessir, I was. Mitch takes a half a dozen 8 x 10 photographs from his ta approaches the witness.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: (handing the photographs to Burke) Were these photographs of the . deceased made by you?

dialogues.speaker: BURKE
dialogues.text: (looking at the pictures) They were, Mitch takes the photographs to the Court Reporter's table

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: The reporter will please mark ‘these photographs People's Exhibit 2A to 2F inclusive for identification, Photographs are tendered to the defense for examination and the People move their admission as evidence, Your witness,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: .No questions and no objection. But Laura suddenly leans forward and whispers to Paul, (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (continues) . Just a moment, Mr. Burke,

dialogues.speaker: C
dialogues.text: 0 Burke sits again in the witness box. Paul gets the photog looks them over,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (continues) Mr, Burke, were the photographs offered here in evidence the only photographs you took that night?

dialogues.speaker: BURKE
dialogues.text: No,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I suppose the others didn't turn out, was that it? “+

dialogues.speaker: BURKE
dialogues.text: (a little offended) All my pictures turn out,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you give these other photographs eC . to the police?

dialogues.speaker: BURKE
dialogues.text: Yes, sir, I did,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Well, what were they, Mr. Burke -~ just some side shots, maybe of the moon or of a black bear scavenging the Thunder Bay dump? De MITCH i Your Honor, I object... I can't see 1 how other photographs are relevant. : The photographs in evidence were introduced to show that the deceased met with a violent death,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your Honor, I would think that any photographs pertaining to the case would be relevant,

dialogues.speaker: . JUDGE WEAVER
dialogues.text: The point is good, Mr. Biegler, Continue, (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: What were the other photographs of, Mr, Burke?

dialogues.speaker: BURKE
dialogues.text: Lieutenant Manion's wife. ,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: You mean these photographs showed how she looked on that night after Barney Quill was killed?

dialogues.speaker: BURKE
dialogues.text: Yes,

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: Your Honor, how Mrs, Manion looked is irrelevant. No evidence has been introduced to connect Mrs, Manion's appearance to the charge of murder,

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE WEAVER
dialogues.text: Sustained,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The photographs can be entered, Your Honor, I just wanted to be sure that the prosecution was not withholding evidence, .

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: (angry) Now look here -- I protest. The defense attorney's persistent attack on the motives of the prosecution,..

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE WEAVER
dialogues.text: (cutting him off) The jury will disregard the remark made by the attorney for the defense, There is no reason to believe that the prosecution has not acted in good faith,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: My apologies to the prosecution and to the Court, but Your Honor, as long as protests are being made, I would like to make a protest myself, I'm willing to take on these two legal giants any time, any place, but in common fairness it ought to be one at a time, I don't want both of them pitching knuckle balls at me at the same time. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: A couple of enrapt jurors nod in agreement, The Judge cat movement and his eyes twinkle,

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE WEAVER
dialogues.text: Mr. Biegler, you seem to be batting a thousand with a bat in each hand, but your point is well taken. Whichever attorney opens with the witness, he alone shall continue with that witness until the witness is excused,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Thanks, Your Honor,

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: Have you finished with this witness, Mr. Biegler?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: No more questions,

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: No questions,

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE WEAVER
dialogues.text: Witness may step down, It's five o'clock and we have had a full day. I will admonish the jury that they ; must not discuss this case among themselves, with their families, | friends or anyone else, The Court : is adjourned until nine a,m, tomorrow morning. He raps his gavel and steps down to his chambers, followe Court Clerk, The Sheriff, "Hear ye - hear ye - this honor is adjourned until nine a,m, tomorrow morning." Immediate newspaper photographers are inside the bar, flash bulbs p catching pictures of all participants, of Laura, Manion a who poses readily,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul, standing inside at the top of the stairs, his singl his arm, watching the spectators crowd up the stairs and courtroom. The Deputy at the door keeps repeating ‘Move s "Don't rush," Take it easy, folks.'' Maida is in the crus stairs, literally being pushed upward, She reaches the la manages to slip out of the mob to Paul, (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MAIDA
dialogues.text: (straightening her hat) We're drawing well today, aren't we?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Where's Parnell?

dialogues.speaker: MAIDA
dialogues.text: Parnell? Why, isn't he here?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: No, and he isn't in his rooming house and hasn't been there all night. You saw him last. Where is he?

dialogues.speaker: MAIDA
dialogues.text: I promised not to tell, so don't ask me. coy a, PAUL ’ What's the big secret. Us

dialogues.speaker: MAIDA
dialogues.text: He thinks you might worry.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Did he fall off the wagon?

dialogues.speaker: MAIDA
dialogues.text: No. He's sober.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Did he go somewhere?

dialogues.speaker: MAIDA
dialogues.text: He did borrow my car for something or other.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: That was smart. He hasn't driven a car in twenty years. He'll kill himself. Where's he going?

dialogues.speaker: MAIDA
dialogues.text: My word is my bond. Holding onto her hat, she steps back into the crush of sp and is carried on into the courtroom.

dialogues.speaker: EXT, HIGHWAY
dialogues.text: Maida's old car comes speeding along, wobbling on a curve veering to the center, forcing another car off on the sho

dialogues.speaker: INT, MAIDA'S CAR
dialogues.text: Parnell, oblivious to danger, singing a rollicking song a of his lungs -- tires screeching as he comes around the c ‘horns HONKING at him in anger. -

dialogues.speaker: EXT, HIGHWAY
dialogues.text: Maida's car zigzags through frightened traffic, speeds on highway. The CAMERA PANS toa sign ona shoulder: "SLOW

dialogues.speaker: INT, COURTROOM
dialogues.text: The spectators are in their seats, the doors of the court Manion and Laura are in their places with Paul. Maida is spectators' bench behind Paul's table. At the prosecution stranger with Dancer and Mitch, The stranger is stooped, grey droopy mustache, a high-domed forehead, Judge Weaver from his chambers and the hall grows quiet as the Sheriff Court to order, .

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE WEAVER
dialogues.text: We will again take up the case of People versus Frederick Manion, Is the defense ready?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir, Your Honor, but the defense observes a third person at the prosecution table, We wonder if the Court shares our curiosity as to his identity.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: I was about to introduce him. Your Honor, this gentleman is Dr. W. Gregory Harcourt, Dr, Harcourt is the People's psychiatrist in this case. We ask that Dr. Harcourt be allowed to sit at our table as an observer,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: What do you want him to observe? -- the constellation of Taurus or the. life and times of a bumblebee ?

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: To observe the defendant, of course ~ as the tirelessly grandstanding defense counsel well knows,

dialogues.speaker: ' PAUL
dialogues.text: Defense has no objection, Your Honor. I only wish to express my relief that the new recruit is not additional legal reinforcement from Lansing, A titter from a couple of jurors, (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: O JUDGE WEAVER
dialogues.text: (rapping) Call the first witness,

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Call Alphonse Paquette,

dialogues.speaker: COURT CLERK
dialogues.text: Alphonse Paquette come forward. Paquette comes from the witness bench into the enclosure, and seated,

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: State your name, please.

dialogues.speaker: PAQUETTE
dialogues.text: Alphonse Paquette.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: You work at the Thunder Bay Inn, don't you, Mr. Paquette? poy PAQUETTE I'm bartender there.

dialogues.speaker: GS MITCH
dialogues.text: Were you working on the night that Barney Quill was shot by Frederick Manion?

dialogues.speaker: PAQUETTE
dialogues.text: I was.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Were you witness to the shooting ? :

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Please tell us in your own words what happened,

dialogues.speaker: PAQUETTE
dialogues.text: I was at a table by the door when Lieutenant Manion came in,

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Did you know Lieutenant Manion by sight and by name? e (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PAQUETTE
dialogues.text: Yessir. :

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Go ahead.

dialogues.speaker: PAQUETTE
dialogues.text: He came in and walked over to the bar and began to shoot. He shot Barney when'he came up to the bar and when Barney fell he stood up on the rail and kept on shooting down at Barney behind the bar. Then he stepped down off the rail and turned around and walked out.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: When Lieutenant Manion entered the bar, how did he appear to you?

dialogues.speaker: PAQUETTE
dialogues.text: Well, he walked slow--kind of deliberate I guess you'd say. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Did he speak to Barney Quill?

dialogues.speaker: PAQUETTE
dialogues.text: Not a word, He just. walked over and pulled out his gun and 'bang!!

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Then he walked out?

dialogues.speaker: PAQUETTE
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: As he walked out, how did he appear ta you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He seemed just like he did when he walked in, Like he was the mailman delivering the mail, He delivered it and left,

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Did he seem excited?

dialogues.speaker: PAQUETTE
dialogues.text: Not that I could see,

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Was he trembling, maybe his hands shaking?

dialogues.speaker: PAQUETTE
dialogues.text: Far as I could see he was as cool as ice,

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: When Lieutenant Manion walked. out of the bar, what did you do?

dialogues.speaker: PAQUETTE
