dialogues.text: Well, it had happened so fast that I guess I was stunned, but then I ran out after him,

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Did you find him outside?

dialogues.speaker: PAQUETTE
dialogues.text: Yes, sir - he was walking away.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Did you speak to him? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PAQUETTE
dialogues.text: Yes, sir, I said, ‘Lieutenant, you'd better not run away from this, !

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Did he reply to you?

dialogues.speaker: PAQUETTE
dialogues.text: He said, 'Do you want some too, Buster?!

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Was he pointing the gun at you?

dialogues.speaker: PAQUETTE
dialogues.text: Sort of,

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Can you be more specific, Mr, Paquette?

dialogues.speaker: PAQUETTE
dialogues.text: Well, he was holding the gun in my direction but the muzzle was low.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: What happened then?

dialogues.speaker: PAQUETTE
dialogues.text: I backed off and he went on,

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: When he said, 'Do you want some too, Buster, ' how was that expressed? Did he shout, was it hysterical, was he hoarse, did his voice tremble?

dialogues.speaker: PAQUETTE
dialogues.text: No, sir, he just said it cool and hard and looked right at me, Se oe “MITCH: Did he appear to be, as far as you could tell, in complete possession of his faculties?

dialogues.speaker: PAQUETTE
dialogues.text: Yes, sir, as far as I could tell.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Your witness, (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: . PAUL
dialogues.text: Cy (places his lure between the pages of the book and rises) Mr. Paquette, did you see Laura Manion, wife of Lieutenant Manion, in the bar that night?

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Your Honor, there he goes again, This is immaterial and irrelevant,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: The prosecution seems to be excessively jumpy, Your Honor, I haven't gone anywhere yet.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE WEAVER
dialogues.text: Let's see where he is going before we object, Mr, Lodwick, Proceed, Mr. Biegler. eee

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Did you see Mrs, Manion in the bar?

dialogues.speaker: PAQUETTE
dialogues.text: She was there,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Do you know when she left?

dialogues.speaker: PAQUETTE
dialogues.text: I don't remember when but she left some time,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Did Barney Quill leave the bar that ! night? ;

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: How long was he gone?

dialogues.speaker: PAQUETTE
dialogues.text: Idon't know exactly.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Do you remember when he returned?

dialogues.speaker: PAQUETTE
dialogues.text: e@ I think he came back around midnight. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: —™ PAUL OO Did you see him enter the bar?

dialogues.speaker: PAQUETTE
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: From which entrance did he ‘come? . From the lobby entrance or the outside entrance? .

dialogues.speaker: PAQUETTE
dialogues.text: It was from the lobby.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: How did he appear to you at that time?

dialogues.speaker: PAQUETTE
dialogues.text: How do you mean? : +

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: You understood the prosecuting attorney very well when he asked that question,

dialogues.speaker: . PAQUETTE
dialogues.text: ! Oh == well, he was just old Barney, oO like usual,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: : : You mean, he was just good-old-sober= reliable-gentle=salt-of-the-earth-friend- to-man Barney?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: : Your Honor, what kind of a question is that?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I withdraw the question, Your: Honor, "Now, Mr. Paquette, had Barney changed his clothes since he left the bar?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paquette hesitates,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (continues) Did he have different clothing on, Mr. Paquette?

dialogues.speaker: PAQUETTE
dialogues.text: I don't remember,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Might his clothes have been different when he returned? That is, might he have changed his clothes?

dialogues.speaker: PAQUETTE
dialogues.text: I couldn't say, I didn't notice,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Was Barney drinking that night?

dialogues.speaker: PAQUETTE
dialogues.text: Well, he always had a few shots while he was talking to the customers, He was friendly,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Good old Barney,’ Now how many shots would you say good old Barney usually had?

dialogues.speaker: PAQUETTE
dialogues.text: I don't know exactly,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Was he drinking more than usual that night?

dialogues.speaker: PAQUETTE
dialogues.text: Not ta my knowledge.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Wasn't he in fact pretty well loaded that night, Mr, Paquette? ’ MITCH Objection, Your Honor, If the deceased was dead drunk it's no defense to this charge,

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE WEAVER
dialogues.text: * Sustained, I suggest you get off this, Mr, Biegler,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Mr. Paquette, what do you call a man who has an insatiable penchant for women?

dialogues.speaker: PAQUETTE
dialogues.text: A what?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Penchant...a desire... appetite, .. passion, ., taste... hunger, (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gd

dialogues.speaker: PAQUETTE
dialogues.text: Well, a ladies' man, I guess -- or maybe just a damned fool, A titter runs through the courtroom,

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE WEAVER
dialogues.text: (rapping his gavel) Just answer the question, Mr. Paquette, The attorneys will provide the wisecracks,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: “What else would you call a man like that, Mr. Paquette?

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: We can't see the drift of this, Your Honor,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: You mean you do see it, Mr, Lodwick,

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE WEAVER
dialogues.text: Take the answer. PAUL . Can you think of another name, Mr, Paquette?

dialogues.speaker: PAQUETTE
dialogues.text: Woman chaser,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: . Try again,

dialogues.speaker: PAQUETTE
dialogues.text: Masher?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Come now, Mr. Paquette, mashers went out with whalebone corsets and hairnets, Did you ever hear the expression ‘wolf?!

dialogues.speaker: PAQUETTE
dialogues.text: Sure, I've heard that, It slipped my mind,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Naturally it would, clanking around in there with all those rusty old mashers, Have you ever known a man who could be called a wolf, Mr. Paquette ? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PAQUETTE
dialogues.text: I'm not sure,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Was Barney Quill a wolf, Mr, Paquette?

dialogues.speaker: PAQUETTE
dialogues.text: I couldn't say.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Or wouldn't,

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Objection,

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE WEAVER
dialogues.text: Sustained. The question was answered, he couldn't say.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Mr. Paquette, when Barney returned from wherever he had been, did he relieve you at the bar?

dialogues.speaker: PAQUETTE
dialogues.text: Yes,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: What did he say when he relieved you?

dialogues.speaker: PAQUETTE
dialogues.text: He said, 'I'll take over, !

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Did he say anything else? Did he whisper anything to you?

dialogues.speaker: PAQUETTE
dialogues.text: (looking away, hesitating) I don't remember he said anything else,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: When you came out from behind the bar, where did you go?

dialogues.speaker: PAQUETTE
dialogues.text: I went over to the table where the Pedersons were sitting, (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: You testified that you were by the door when Lieutenant Manion came in, Was that the reason you were by the door, because the Pedersons' table was there?

dialogues.speaker: PAQUETTE
dialogues.text: Yes,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: And how long was it before Lieutenant Manion came in?

dialogues.speaker: PAQUETTE
dialogues.text: I don't know exactly -- maybe thirty minutes,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: You remained at the Pedersons' table all this time?

dialogues.speaker: PAQUETTE
dialogues.text: Yes -- they're friends of mine,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Isn't there also a window by that table?

dialogues.speaker: PAQUETTE
dialogues.text: I think so.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: You think so? How long have you worked at the Thunder Bay Inn, Mr. Paquette?

dialogues.speaker: PAQUETTE
dialogues.text: About six or seven years,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Well,. does that window beside that table sometimes vanish and then appear again? Does it come and go in a ghostly fashion?

dialogues.speaker: PAQUETTE
dialogues.text: No sir. it's there all the time.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Did you happen to look out of this window while you were talking to your friends?

dialogues.speaker: PAQUETTE
dialogues.text: I might have. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: oO

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: When you were looking out of this window, were you looking for something special?

dialogues.speaker: PAQUETTE
dialogues.text: No -= I wasn't looking for anything,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Didn't Barney Quill tell you to go to the window and watch for Lieutenant Manion? . Paquette freezes, licks his lips nervously,

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Lobject, Your Honor, Counsel has gone far afield,

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE WEAVER
dialogues.text: Perhaps so, Mr. Lodwick, but there seems-to-be no real offense. Take the answer,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Did he tell you to watch for Lieutenant Manion?

dialogues.speaker: PAQUETTE
dialogues.text: He did not.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Mr. Paquette, Barney Quill was quite a marksman, wasn't he, with guns? He'd won prizes for. shooting, hadn't he?

dialogues.speaker: PAQUETTE
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: He was well known for his skill, wasn't he? He also kept loving cups, pictures and write-ups about his shooting on display behind the bar, didn't he?

dialogues.speaker: PAQUETTE
dialogues.text: Yes,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Did he keep any guns behind the bar?

dialogues.speaker: PAQUETTE
dialogues.text: Well, he might have. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Isn't it a fact that there are three concealed pistol racks behind that bar, Mr. Paquette?

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Your honor, the defendant's plea is one of insanity, not self-defense,

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE WEAVER
dialogues.text: I'm sure Mr, Biegler has not forgotten that fact, Mr. Lodwick, Take the answer.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Are there concealed gun racks behind the bar? .

dialogues.speaker: PAQUETTE
dialogues.text: Yes,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: How many people knew about those gun racks?

dialogues.speaker: PAQUETTE
dialogues.text: I couldn't say.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Isn't it a fact that Barney sometimes took the pistols out of those racks, spinning them on his fingers, showing off his prowess for his customers?

dialogues.speaker: PAQUETTE
dialogues.text: I don't remember,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Try to remember, did you ever see him do this yourself?.. .

dialogues.speaker: PAQUETTE.
dialogues.text: Once or twice he did, :

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: That's all, Mr. Paquette,

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: No further questions,

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE WEAVER
dialogues.text: Witness may step down.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Call George Lemon, (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: As Paquette leaves the enclosure and Mr. Lemon comes in a sworn = at the prosecution table, Mitch huddles with Danc

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: (continues) Biegler's going cff in all directions, What's he getting at?

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: I've a feeling he's afraid of what we'll get at. Mr, Biegler's putting up a smoke screen for some reason. Mitch rises to begin examination of Lemon.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: State your name, please,

dialogues.speaker: LEMON
dialogues.text: Gecrge Lemon,

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: What kind of work do you do, Mr. Lemon? .

dialogues.speaker: LEMON
dialogues.text: I'm caretaker of the tourist park in Thunder Bay. I see that the place is clean and orderly, I check people in and check them out and lock the gate at night. -

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: What is your authority for these duties?

dialogues.speaker: LEMON
dialogues.text: I'm paid by Mastcdon township and I'm a deputy sheriff - just courtesy, sort of ==.no Pay. : :

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Mr. and Mrs, Frederick Manion lived in a trailer in your park, didn't they?

dialogues.speaker: LEMON
dialogues.text: Yessir,

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Did you see Lieutenant Manion on the night of the fifteenth? The night Barney Quill was killed?

dialogues.speaker: LEMON
dialogues.text: Yessir, (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you tell the Court about how and when you saw Lieutenant Manion?

dialogues.speaker: LEMON
dialogues.text: About one a.m, a knock on my door waked me up, I went to the door and Lieutenant Manion was standing there. He said, 'You better take me, Mr, Lemon, because I just shot Barney Quill,' I told him to go back to his trailer and that I would call the State Police,

dialogues.speaker: ' MITCH
dialogues.text: How did Lieutenant Manion appear to you when he asked you to take him? I mean, was he trembling, excited, ' frightened, or what? ~ : ween

dialogues.speaker: LEMON
dialogues.text: He seemed right straight forward, He said what he had to say and then did what Itold him, There wasn't any fuss.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Oo Did he appear to be as far as you could tell in complete possession of his faculties? |

dialogues.speaker: LEMON
dialogues.text: As far as I could tell, yes sir,

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Take the witness,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (rising) Mr.: Lemon, did you go to Manion's ‘trailer? . .

dialogues.speaker: LEMON
dialogues.text: Yes sir,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Did you see Mrs, Manion at the trailer?

dialogues.speaker: LEMON
dialogues.text: She was standing outside and she said, 'Look what Barney did to me, !

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: @ Objection, Your Honor, Witness is not answering the question. He-was asked, 'Did you see Mrs, Manion, * (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 80 CONTINUED: (i4)

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE WEAVER
dialogues.text: Strike the answer and the jury will disregard, Take the question again, Mr. Biegler,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Did you see Mrs, Manion?

dialogues.speaker: LEMON
dialogues.text: Yes sir.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: What was her appearance?

dialogues.speaker: LEMON
dialogues.text: Well -- she was a mess,

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Objection, No evidence has been introduced ta make Mrs, Manion's appearance relevant to this case,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (angry) No evidence was introduced to make Barney Quill's appearance relevant but you didn't object to my question then, Is that because you know that Quill bathed and changed and cooled off after he had raped and beat the hell out of this poor woman?

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Your honor, everybody in this courtroom is being tried except Frederick Manion, I must protest Mr. Biegler's attacks on...

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (cutting in} This is a cross-examination in a murder case, not a high school debate! What are you and Dancer trying to do? -- railroad this soldier into the clink? Judge Weaver is pounding with his gavel and finally the r

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE WEAVER
dialogues.text: Mr. Biegler, you're an experienced attorney and you know better than to make such an outburst, (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: JUDGE WEAVER (cont'd) I will not tolerate intemperance of this sort. If you once again try the patience of this Court, I shall hold you in contempt.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I apologize, Your Honor. It won't happen again,

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE WEAVER
dialogues.text: The witness! answer will be stricken and the jury will disregard the answer. Now you may proceed, Mr, Biegler,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Mr. Lemon, on the night Lieutenant Manion awakened you and turned himself in, had you been awakened before ~~‘had anything else disturbed your slumbers?

dialogues.speaker: LEMON
dialogues.text: No, sir,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: There were no soldiers singing?

dialogues.speaker: LEMON
dialogues.text: No, sir, not in my park after ten o'clock.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: There were no women screaming?

dialogues.speaker: LEMON
dialogues.text: Well, those screams were down by. ‘the gate. , ea .

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Objection, objection,

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE WEAVER
dialogues.text: I see no reason for objection yet, Mr. Lodwick,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Tell us about those screams, Mr. Lemon,

dialogues.speaker: LEMON
dialogues.text: I didn't hear 'em myself, There were some tourists from Ohio in the park and they heard them and told me about it the next day. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (oO Now, Mr. Lodwick.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: This testimony is incompetent, hearsay -- irrelevant, immaterial, inconclusive --

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (cutting in) That's too much for me. The witness is yours, Mr. Lodwick,

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: {caught in mid-air by Paul's sudden switch) Huh? -- oh, no questions,

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE WEAVER
dialogues.text: Witness may step down, Call your next witness, - wa Te The next witness is SERGEANT DURGO of the Michigan State As he is called and sworn, Paul, at the counsel table, wh Maida over the railing which separates them, — PAUL When we break you'd better phone that Army psychiatrist. Tell him to be here day after tomorrow,

dialogues.speaker: MAIDA
dialogues.text: Will do. PAUL . Will you please tell me where Parne. = has gone? : MAIDA : a Won't do,

dialogues.speaker: , PAUL
dialogues.text: You're fired, =:

dialogues.speaker: MAIDA
dialogues.text: You can't fire me until you pay me. Sergeant Durgo is now on the stand. He is a strong~lookin man of about forty, direct, thoughtful, honest. Mitch tak direct examination, (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: State your name and your occupation, please.

dialogues.speaker: DURGO
dialogues.text: Detective Sergeant James Durgo. Michigan State Police,

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Were you called to Thunder Bay by Deputy Sherifi Lemon of Thunder Bay on the night that Barney Quill was shot and killed?

dialogues.speaker: DURGO
dialogues.text: Yes sir, Iwas. My companion officer and I were the first to. be called in on the case.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Sergeant Durgo, when you arrived at the Manion trailer, who was there?

dialogues.speaker: . DURGO
dialogues.text: Lieutenant Manion and his wife were there,

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: What did Lieutenant Manion say to you?

dialogues.speaker: DURGO
dialogues.text: He said that his wife had had some trouble with Barney Quill and that he had gone to the tavern and shot Quill, He asked us whether Quill was dead or not and we told him he was,

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: How did Lieutenant Manion take this information?

dialogues.speaker: DURGO
dialogues.text: He didn't seem surprised,

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: What did you do then, Sergeant Durgo?

dialogues.speaker: DURGO
dialogues.text: I asked for the gun he had used. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: c) : MITCH Did you take Lieutenant Manion to the County jail here in Iron City on _that same night?

dialogues.speaker: DURGO
dialogues.text: Yes sir. We drove the Lieutenant down with his wife.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: On the drive to Iron City did the Lieutenant talk further about the shooting ?

dialogues.speaker: DURGO
dialogues.text: He remarked that if he had the whole thing to do over again he would still do it. He also said that he had thought about it before going to the bar and had decided that Quill shouldn't be allowed to live,

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Through all this -- at the trailer -- the drive to Iron City, how did Lieutenant Manion appear to you?

dialogues.speaker: DURGO
dialogues.text: He was very quiet most of the time and seemed clear-headed,

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: You would say he was calm?

dialogues.speaker: DURGO
dialogues.text: Yes -- calm.

dialogues.speaker: __. MITCH
dialogues.text: As.far.as you could tell, would. . = you say that he was in complete possession of his faculties?

dialogues.speaker: DURGO
dialogues.text: He seemed so to me.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Your witness,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Now sergeant, you testified that the Lieutenant told you he had shot ’ Barney Quill after he had learned @ that his wife had had 'some trouble! with Quill, Were those the words the Lieutenant used? 'Some trouble?! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DURGO
dialogues.text: No sir, Those were my words -- not his.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Was it your notion to come here and use your own words?

dialogues.speaker: DURGO
dialogues.text: No sir, it was not,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Was the suggestion made to you to call it 'some trouble! by a person now in this room?

dialogues.speaker: DURGO
dialogues.text: (looking toward . Mitch) Yessir, it was.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Now would you please tell the Court what words Lieutenant Manion actually used to describe the 'trouble' his wife had had? o

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Objection, your honor. We've been over this before. This information would not be relevant to any issue before the Court.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: This statement concerning 'some trouble' was brought out during the direct examination of Sergeant Durgo. Up to. now the prosecution has. adroitly ! restricted all of their witnesses’ testimonies where Laura Manion has : been concerned, But now the cat is out of the bag and it's fair game for me to chase it,

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE WEAVER
dialogues.text: This is a sore point, Mr. Biegler, and it's getting sorer, I'd like to hear what the prosecution has to say. Mitch and Dancer confer for a moment. Then Mitch rises, eo : (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Your honor, the burden is on the defense to prove temporary insanity at the time of the shooting. If the reason for the alleged insanity is important to this case then that is a matter for a competent witness -- an expert on the subject of the human mind, What the defense is trying to do is introduce some sensational material for the purposes of obscuring the real issues,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Your honor, how can the jury accurately estimate the testimony being given here unless they first know the reason behind this whole trial -- why Lieutenant Manion shot Quill? The prosecution would like to separate the motive from the act. That's like trying to take the core from an apple witheut breaking the skin, Well, the core of our defense is that the defendant's temporary insanity was triggered by this so-called 'trouble! with Quill, I beg the Court to let me cut into the apple.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Our objection still stands, your honor, The courtroom is silent. All attention upon Judge Weaver. is why he is called judge, because alone he must decide w just or unjust. Judge Weaver, in deep study, takes out hi winds it, the SOUND clearly heard in the silent room, He at Paul, Manion, Laura, Dancer and Mitch. He looks out ov slack-mouthed thrill seekers among the spectators and fro POV we, too, look at all these people, Finally the judge back in his chair, puts his watch back.in his pocket,

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE WEAVER
dialogues.text: I'll take the answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A wave of muted excitement travels through the courtroom. gratified and triumphant, rises to continue the cross-exa Mitch rises, intending to protest the judge's decision, b by a touch on his arm from Dancer,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Sergeant Durgo, tell the Court how Lieutenant Manion described the trouble his wife had with Barney Quill, (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: a

dialogues.speaker: DURGO
dialogues.text: He told us that Quill had raped his wife. ,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Can you recall generally what Lieutenant Manion told you about this rape?

dialogues.speaker: DURGO
dialogues.text: Yessir. He said he'd been asleep since right after dinner and that he was waked up by some noise -~ screams he thought. That he got up and opened the trailer door and went outside and his wife came running out of the dark and fell into his arms.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL 7
dialogues.text: You saw his wife in the trailer. How did she look?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She was a little hysterical and she'd been pretty badly beaten up. She had big black bruises over her face and arms.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Did she tell you the story about the rape and beating?

dialogues.speaker: DURGO
dialogues.text: She did,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Did she take you to the place where it had happened?

dialogues.speaker: DURGO
dialogues.text: Yessir. The next morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you find anything there -- any sort of evidence pertaining to what Mrs. Manion had told you?

dialogues.speaker: DURGO
dialogues.text: On the lane in the woods we found some tire tracks and some dog tracks and a glasses case with some horn- rimmed glasses inside, (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: eo os DURGO (cont'd) Co We also looked for a -- uh -- a certain undergarment of Mrs, Manion's, but we didn't find it,

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE WEAVER
dialogues.text: Will the attorneys from both sides approach the bench please? Paul, Dancer and Mitch come to the Judge's bench, The Jud leans over to look down at them and their conversation is in a low monotone.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE WEAVER
dialogues.text: (continues) Mr. Biegler, you finally got your rape into the case and I think all the details should be made very clear to the jury. Do you agree, - Mr, Lodwick?

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Absolutely.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE WEAVER
dialogues.text: What exactly was the undergarment Oo just referred to?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Panties, your honor.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE WEAVER
dialogues.text: Do you expect this subject to come up again?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Yea siz.

dialogues.speaker: / JUDGE
dialogues.text: There's a certain light connotation : attached to the word ‘panties. ' Can we find another name for them?

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: I never heard my wife call 'em anything else.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE WEAVER
dialogues.text: Mr. Biegler?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I'm a bachelor, your honor.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE WEAVER
dialogues.text: OQ That's a great help. Mr. Dancer?

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: When I was overseas during the war, Your Honor, I learned a French word but it might be slightly suggestive.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE WEAVER
dialogues.text: Most French words are. All right, go back to your places, The attorneys return to their tables.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE WEAVER
dialogues.text: (continues) For the benefit of the jury, but more ' especially for the spectators, the — eS eeettsundderrgarment referred to in the ‘ testimony was, to be exact, Mrs. Manion's panties. A snicker goes through the room, Judge Weaver waits for q again.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE WEAVER
dialogues.text: (continues) : Oo I wanted you to get your snickerin, over and done with. This pair of panties will be mentioned again in the course of the trial and when that happens there will not be one laugh, one snicker, one giggle or even one smirk, in my courtroom, There isn't anything comic about a pair of panties which figure in the violent death of one man and in the possible incarceration of another,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A long pause, -a pin drop can be heard.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE WEAVER
dialogues.text: (continues) Proceed, Mr. Biegler,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Sergeant, did you further investigate Mrs. Manion's story?

dialogues.speaker: DURGO
dialogues.text: Yessir. I asked a lot of questions -- like did anyone hear the screams from up by the gate that night. We found @ some people in the tourist park who had heard the screams, (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Go ahead, What else did you do in your investigation?

dialogues.speaker: DURGO
dialogues.text: Imade Mrs, Manion tell her story several times,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I suppose you were looking for variance in her story?

dialogues.speaker: DURGO
dialogues.text: Yessir, but there wasn't any.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Did you give Mrs. Manion a lie- detector test?

dialogues.speaker: MITCH .
dialogues.text: Objection, A polygraph test is inadmissible evidence in our courts,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Ionly asked if he gave a test. I didn't ask the results,

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE WEAVER
dialogues.text: Take the answer,

dialogues.speaker: DURGO
dialogues.text: I gave her a lie-detector test at her request,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Now after all this investigation, did you believe Mrs. Manion?

dialogues.speaker: DURGO
dialogues.text: I did,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Even after the lie-detector test?

dialogues.speaker: DURGO
dialogues.text: Yessir,

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Your honor, I object to that question and answer, It constitutes flagrant, sneaking subterfuge on the part of the defense counsel, » (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE WEAVER
dialogues.text: Objection sustained. Ladies and gentlemen of the jury, a polygraph or lie~detector test is not admissible evidence because no one has ever been sure but what some people can lie even to a lie-detector and get away , with it, Go ahead with your field day, Mr, Biegler,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (a half-grin) Thank you, Your Honor. But in any case, Sergeant Durgo, you yourself in your heart and mind were quite convinced of Mrs. Manion's honesty.

dialogues.speaker: DURGO
dialogues.text: Yessir. ‘ PAUL That's all.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Just a moment, He and Dancer are conferring -- Mitch nodding to what Dan saying. Mitch rises, ‘

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: (coritinues) Sergeant Durgo, did you look for the panties elsewhere than the lane in the woods?

dialogues.speaker: DURGO
dialogues.text: We looked in Barney Quill's car and his room in the hotel, We couldn't find the panties.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Do you know why’ Mrs, Manion requested a lie~detector test?

dialogues.speaker: DURGO
dialogues.text: I know what she said,

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: What was that?

dialogues.speaker: DURGO
dialogues.text: She said she wanted everybody to believe her story because she knew it would help her husband, (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: That was the only reason she gave?

dialogues.speaker: DURGO
dialogues.text: I don't remember anything else, She said she had already sworn to her husband and she wanted everybody else to believe it, too. Dancer is riveted, Paul's face is tight. Laura's lips are tremulous. Maida compulsively closes her eyes. Dancer ris and whispers to Mitch,

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Sergeant Durgo, did Mrs, Manion tell + you how she had sworn to her husband?

dialogues.speaker: DURGO
dialogues.text: Yessir, She said she had sworn on a rosary. ~

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: A moment, your honor, (he again confers with Dancer and returns to the witness) Sergeant, ‘this lane in the woods -- what is it used for -- where does it go?

dialogues.speaker: DURGO
dialogues.text: It used to be a logging road -- doesn't go any place -- it just stops.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Who uses it now?

dialogues.speaker: DBURGO
dialogues.text: I think it's a road that kids. drive down to park.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: You mean, it's a lovers' lane,

dialogues.speaker: DURGO
dialogues.text: I think so, yes sir.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: The witness is yours, Mr. Biegler.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: No questions,

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: Witness may step down, Paul glances at Dancer, Dancer smiles and nods as if to s "Yes, I've caught on,"

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: In view of the evidence concerning rape which your honor has ruled admissible, the prosecution asks for a thirty minute recess in order to bring in another witness whom we had not anticipated using.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE WEAVER
dialogues.text: Can you get the witness in that length of time ?

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Yes sir. JUDGE WEAVER ee Very well, The Court is recessed for thirty minutes, In the general hubbub of recess, Paul turns to Laura and

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Why didn't you tell me about that rosary?

dialogues.speaker: MANION
dialogues.text: We forgot it.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: We didn't forget it, Manny said maybe we ought not to tell that again,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It might have looked like something else -- like I didn't believe her.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: How much more didn't you tell me?

dialogues.speaker: MANION
dialogues.text: Everything else. We told you everything else.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Is that right, Laura? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: {a hesitation, a CO) glance at Manion) Yes, everything else,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Well, the fat's in the fire now. Get this -- both of you. When you get on the stand I want you to tell the truth. Don't tell anything but the truth. Don't try to lie, don't try to conceal or you'll be skinned alive. Dancer's going to start moving in.

dialogues.speaker: INT, COURTROOM
dialogues.text: DR. DOMPIERRE is on the stand. A pleasant faced, bespecta bald-headed little doctor, Dancer is examining. DANCER. Doctor, did you have occasion to come to the county jail on the night of August oe the fifteenth of this year?

dialogues.speaker: G
dialogues.text: I did,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ‘ DANCER Who called you to the jail?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: i The police authorities,

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: What did they want you to do?

dialogues.speaker: . .. DOMPIERRE
dialogues.text: ‘They wanted-me‘to make a test for the presence of sperm on the person ofa Mrs, Frederick Manion, I made the test.

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: In making this test, what was your conclusion?

dialogues.speaker: DOMPIERRE
dialogues.text: Negative. There was none,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: e Your witness, Mr. Biegler. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Doctor, in making your test, did you notice any bruises or marks on Mrs. Manion at that time?

dialogues.speaker: DOMPIERRE
dialogues.text: Idid.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Were you asked to determine the reason for these bruises?

dialogues.speaker: DOMPIERRE
dialogues.text: I was not.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Where did you do the laboratory work on the test for sperm?

dialogues.speaker: DOMPIERRE
dialogues.text: a . Saint Margaret's Hospital in this Ss -eitye—-

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Who worked the slides up for you?

dialogues.speaker: DOMPIERRE
dialogues.text: A technician at the hospital.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: What kind of a technician?

dialogues.speaker: DOMPIERRE
dialogues.text: Oh, X-Ray -- like that.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Was he a pathologist or an expert in laboratory work having to do with human reproduction?

dialogues.speaker: DOMPIERRE
dialogues.text: He was just a technician,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Woulda't it have been better to have these'slides worked up by a pathologist or an expert in this field?

dialogues.speaker: DOMPIERRE
dialogues.text: Yes, but the police were in a hurry and I knew this young fellow came on at seven in the morning.
(CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Wouldn't it have been especially better to wait for an expert if the possible question of rape hung on the result?

dialogues.speaker: DOMPIERRE
dialogues.text: It would have been,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Now, Doctor, in the newspaper on the evening of August sixteen it was stated that you had found no evidence of rape. Is that true?

dialogues.speaker: DOMPIERRE
dialogues.text: It is not true. I made no such statement,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Did you form an opinion about whether Mrs, Manion had been raped?

dialogues.speaker: DOMPIERRE
dialogues.text: No, sir,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Why didn't you form an‘ opinion?

dialogues.speaker: DOMPIERRE
dialogues.text: It's impossible to tell if a mature married woman has been raped,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: No further questions.

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: Doctor, did you have an opinion about whether or not she had any recent relations with a man? - ot DOMPIERRE Yes. .

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: State your opinion,

dialogues.speaker: DOMPIERRE
dialogues.text: Insofar as no sperm was present, it didn't appear that she had had recent relations with a man,

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: That's all. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: One more question, Doctor, That no evidence was present in her body does not mean she wasn't raped, does it?

dialogues.speaker: DOMPIERRE
dialogues.text: No,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Do you know what constitutes rape under the law?

dialogues.speaker: DOMPIERRE
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. Violation is sufficient for rape, There need not be a completion.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: No more questions,

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE WEAVER
dialogues.text: Witness may step down.

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: The People recall Alphonse Paquette to the stand, Paquette comes forward,

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE WEAVER
dialogues.text: You're still under oath, Mr. Paquette. Paquette goes to the witness box.

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: Your Honor, since counsel for the defense has forced the question of rape, it becomes necessary to take this additional testimony from Mr, Paquette. ui) (to Paquette)’ Mr. Paquette, will you take a look at Mrs, Manion, sitting there at the defense table? Was she dressed in this manner on the night of the shooting?

dialogues.speaker: PAQUETTE
dialogues.text: No,

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: How was she dressed that night? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PAQUETTE
dialogues.text: I recollect she had on a real tight skirt and a sweater-kind-of-thing sort of glued on, She was wearing a pair of red shoes with high heels...

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: Was she wearing hose?

dialogues.speaker: PAQUETTE
dialogues.text: No, she was bare-legged,

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: Was she wearing a hat?

dialogues.speaker: PAQUETTE
dialogues.text: No. Three women on the jury, three nice respectable matrons, gotten a pinched look about their faces.

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: Mr. Paquette, what kind of hair does Mrs. Manion have under that hat?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: We'll be glad to show the Court Mrs. Manion's hair, Mrs, Manion, will you take off your hat, please? Laura jerks her hat off, pulls a couple of hairpins and d shakes out her glamorous tresses,

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: Thank you, Counselor, Mr. Paquette, was she wearing glasses that night ?

dialogues.speaker: PAQUETTE
dialogues.text: I think she was when she played

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: Considering the tight skirt and the tight.sweater and the bare legs, what was the result in her appearance?

dialogues.speaker: PAQUETTE
dialogues.text: Well.....

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: Would you say Mrs. Manion's appearance on that night was deliberately voluptuous and enticing? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PAQUETTE
dialogues.text: Well, you could pretty much see everything she had.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Your Honor, defense will concede that Mrs, Manion when dressed informally is an astonishingly beautiful woman, As a matter of fact, it's pretty easy to understand why her husband became temporarily ‘deranged when he saw such beauty bruised and torn by a beast, Judge Weaver blows his nose to keep from laughing.

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: Your Honor, I protest. Mr. Biegler is perhaps the least disciplined and the most completely out-of-order attorney I've ever seen in a courtroom. A laugh goes through the courtroom,

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE WEAVER
dialogues.text: (rapping) Jury will ignore Mr, Biegler's oration.

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: Was Mrs. Manion drinking heavily that night?

dialogues.speaker: PAQUETTE
dialogues.text: Well, I sold her six drinks myself and Barney came over and got some more for her.. I don't remember how many.

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: ‘Would you say that Mrs, Manion was, tight? :

dialogues.speaker: PAQUETTE
dialogues.text: She was high all right.

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: What did she do to make you think she was high? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PAQUETTE
dialogues.text: She took off her shoes and went bare~footed and when she played pinball she would kind of swish around to give the machine english,

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: You mean she was flipping her hips around?

dialogues.speaker: PAQUETTE
dialogues.text: Yes,

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: Anything else?

dialogues.speaker: PAQUETTE
dialogues.text: When she'd made a good score she ‘squealed -——-—_ like women do,

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: She was playing pinball with Barney Quill, wasn't she?

dialogues.speaker: PAQUETTE
dialogues.text: Yes sir, .

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: What was her attitude toward Barney Quill?

dialogues.speaker: . PAQUETTE
dialogues.text: Friendly, I guess you could call it, ‘ DANCER More than friendly perhaps?

dialogues.speaker: PAQUETTE
dialogues.text: -I thought so. .

dialogues.speaker: , DANCER
dialogues.text: Why did you think so?

dialogues.speaker: . PAQUETTE
dialogues.text: She would kind of lean on him and a couple of times she bumped him with her hip, At the defense table Manion is pale and strained, Laura h her lip between her teeth. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: Would you say Mrs. Manion was making a play for Barney Quill?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Objection, That calls for an assumption on the part of the witness, your honor,

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: I withdraw the question. Would you say that Mrs, Manion was free and easy with Barney Quill?

dialogues.speaker: PAQUETTE
dialogues.text: | I would,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your witness, Mr. Biegler.

dialogues.speaker: , . PAUL
dialogues.text: (rising) Mr. Paquette, the attorney for the People asked you if Mrs, Manion was tight and you said she was high. } Speaking as a bartender, what is 5 the distinction between the two?

dialogues.speaker: PAQUETTE
dialogues.text: } I don't think I understand,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: When we say a person is tight we ' usually mean they're a little stupid with drink, isn't that right?

dialogues.speaker: PAQUETTE
dialogues.text: I guess that's about it, yes. ° ‘PAUL But if they're high they're gay and enjoying themselves?

dialogues.speaker: PAQUETTE
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: - So in other words, Mrs, Manion was happy. Now is there anything wrong with being happy in the Thunder Bay Inn? e PAQUETTE No. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Thunder Bay itself is a resort, isn't it? Swimming, fishing, that sort of thing.

dialogues.speaker: PAQUETTE
dialogues.text: Yes,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Is it unusual to see a barefooted woman in Thunder Bay?-

dialogues.speaker: PAQUETTE
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: So Mrs, Manion taking off her shoes in Thunder Bay doesn't necessarily mean that she was being unladylike, does it?

dialogues.speaker: PAQUETTE
dialogues.text: I guess not,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Yes or no,

dialogues.speaker: PAQUETTE
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: You testified that Mrs, Manion was squealing, jumping up and down and swishing her hips at the pinball machine. Was she creating a disturbance, was she attracting a crowd?

dialogues.speaker: PAQUETTE
dialogues.text: No,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Were all of the men in the bar standing around watching Mrs. Manion?

dialogues.speaker: PAQUETTE
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: But you were conscious of Mrs, Manion, enough so that you can tell us how she acted, . (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PAQUETTE
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: And certainly Barney Quill was conscious ‘of Mrs, Manion, because he was playing pinball with her, Wouldn't you say so?

dialogues.speaker: PAQUETTE
dialogues.text: Yes,

dialogues.speaker: . PAUL
dialogues.text: So it seerns that only you and Barney Quill were acutely aware of Mrs, Manion and her actions and appearance, Perhaps Barney, when he came to get some drinks, perhaps he winked and said, ‘Alphonse, I'm going to take this babe out and rape her. ' oa

dialogues.speaker: . PAQUETTE
dialogues.text: (angry) No, no he didn't!

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: {boring in =~ raising his voice) And maybe you said, 'Do it once for me. The courtroom is rumbling,

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: (shouting -- simultaneously with Paul) Objection, objection... Those aren't questions. Counsel is attacking the witness." i :

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (contemptuously) No more questions.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE WEAVER
dialogues.text: ° (restoring order) The Court has had about all of this dogfight it can take for one day. And I'm sure the jury is immensely confused, tired and hungry. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: . MITCH
dialogues.text: Your Honor, that was the last of the People's witnesses,

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE WEAVER
dialogues.text: Very well, Mr. Lodwick. Tomorrow the defense will take over and, with expedition, prayer and a little self- discipline on part of counsel, perhaps we can reach an end by Saturday night. The Court stands adjourned until nine tomorrow morning,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SHOOTING through the windshield, wipers frantically swipi heavy rain, Parnell behind the wheel,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Parnell is in need of a shave and a clean shirt, He is do trying to stay awake as he drives,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through the wet glass the road curves ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His eyelids drooping and closing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A big truck comes barreling around the curve. The hood of car is wobbling into the center of the road,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The approaching lights of the truck flash in his face, aw his doze and he turns the car back into its proper lane, roars past, claxon horn SOUNDING angrily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The highway stretches straight ahead into the night. The wipers slap in a deadly lullaby. ‘

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The SOUND of the wipers over -- his eyelids are drooping finally close.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A curve ahead and a side road running straight off at the the curve. A barnyard gate closes the side road. A barn l the gate. The hood of the car does not turn into the curv at the gate, crashes through.

dialogues.speaker: INT, HOSPITAL CORRIDOR
dialogues.text: Sheriff Battisfore and an INTERNE are talking quietly in dimly lighted corridor, The elevator door opens and Paul wet raincoat, hat dripping. He hurries to Battisfore and

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: How is he, Sheriff?

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF
dialogues.text: The doctor here says he's all right.

dialogues.speaker: INTERNE
dialogues.text: (opening the door to a hospital room) He's banged up a little but there doesn't seem to be anything else. We'd like to watch him for a day or so. Paul, the Sheriff and the Interne enter the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are several beds in the room and in one of them lie a strip.of bandage across his forehead, his eyes closed. Sheriff:and:the Interne cdme into the room, ‘halt before speak in low tones,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: What's the damage?

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF
dialogues.text: He wrecked a gate and a barn door -- and he hasn't got a driver's license, He'll have to appear in the JP Court when he's able, Old fool. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PARNELL
dialogues.text: CQ (opening one eye) aa Speak kindly of the dead,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: You mind if Ihave a minute with the corpse?

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF
dialogues.text: Sure, Polly. The Sheriff and the Interne leave,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Was it worth trying to kill yourself for? -- whatever it is you've been up to?

dialogues.speaker: PARNELL
dialogues.text: How's the trial going? "PAUL Os I'm making a lot of noise but Dancer's racking up the points. Come on - where've you been?

dialogues.speaker: PARNELL
dialogues.text: Quill hired Mary Pilant up north of the Soo, Struck me funny he'd go all the way up there just to hire somebody to work for him, I been up there nosing around,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Find anything of use?

dialogues.speaker: PARNELL
dialogues.text: Not till I looked up her birth certificate. Born in Blind River, Ontario - 1934 - out of wedlock.‘ Mother: was:a-waitress: “named Simone Pilant. Father waa a : _ lumberjack - name - Barney Quill.

dialogues.speaker: INT, LOBBY
dialogues.text: It is very late. The lobby is deserted except for a young He's reading the sports page in the newspaper, Through th entrance we see a car pull up outside and Paul, holding h the wind and rain, gets out of the car, hurries up the st the lobby. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I'd like to see Miss Pilant.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: She's gone to bed, mister.

dialogues.speaker: . PAUL
dialogues.text: It's important,

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: Real important?

dialogues.speaker: . PAUL
dialogues.text: Yes, real important. The porter plugs into the small switchboard and buzzes se

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: (into phone) Miss Pilant? Sorry if I woke you up. There's a guy to see you, Says it's real important. (to Paul) What's your -~

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Paul Biegler.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: (into phone) Biegler ----- eoewwenenen= okay, He disconnects the plug.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: (continues; to Paul) She says it's not important enough.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Call her back, Tell her I mentioned Blind River, Ontario, He leaves the desk, goes through the door which leads fro to the barroom. Puzzled, the porter looks after him, plug switchboard again.

dialogues.speaker: INT, HOTEL BAR
dialogues.text: Not many customers are here, The jukebox plays softly. Pa down the short flight of steps from the lobby, approaches (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Paquette, polishing a glass, sees Paul, stacks the glass back bar, moves warily down to meet the lawyer.

dialogues.speaker: PAQUETTE
dialogues.text: Drinking, Mr. Biegler, or just snooping?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I'L try a little of both, Alphonse. Why don't we start with a beer, Paquette draws a beer, places it before Paul,

dialogues.speaker: PAQUETTE
dialogues.text: On the house - and that's all you get - abeer, No questions ~ no answers, I got my belly full of you in the courtroom, When you've finished that - blow - and don't take too long about it,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: As long as this is on the house how about that much of rye to go with it? Paquette glares at Paul, snaps a bottle off the back shel a shot glasa next to Paul's beer and pours,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (continuing) I'm just a lawyer doing my job. What are you so afraid of, Al? He tosses off the drink, takes a sip of beer. Paquette wa with glum anger. Paquette's eyes are drawn to a point beh Paul turns.. Mary Pilant, dressed in skirt anda coat-swea just entered the bar from the lobby. Her face is pale and She approaches Paul, waits for him to speak,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Could we have some privacy? Silently she leads the way to the far table by the window leading to the outside. Paquette watches them anxiously. Paul draws a chair out for Mary and sits beside her.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (continues) I owe you an apology, Miss Pilant, I was a little rough when I was here before, I didn't know Mr. Quill was your father,

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: How did you find that out? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Friend of mine did a bit of what Al there would call snooping. Oh, could Ibuy you a drink?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: It's a long drive from Iron City in this kind of a night, Mr, Biegler,

dialogues.speaker: . PAUL
dialogues.text: You mean why am I here?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: You didn't come just to apologize,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No - no - but the apology was part of it. Tell you the truth I thought it might thaw you out just a little. Now all I want you to do, Miss Pilant, is listen for just a few minutes, I need some strong evidence to back up Laura Manion's story about the rape. The prosecution is going to attack that story pretty hard - and if the jury thinks she's lying it could turn their decision against Manion,

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Well, isn't she lying? Barney didn't do what she said he did, He couldn't have,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: What did you know about your father?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All I needed to know = that he took care of me = and of my mother ~ for as long as she lived, He would have’ married her, but he was already married, When he finally got a divorce it was too late, but he was always there when I needed him. Now that's what I know about my father, Mr, Biegler, Will that - as you say ~ back up Laura Manion's story?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Miss Pilant, I'm not trying to get at you or hurt you, (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: PAUL (cont'd) I appreciate your affection for your father -- but as a lawyer I have had to learn that people are not just good or just bad, but many things - and I think maybe Barney Quill was many things ---

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I don't want...

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Now just ~ hear me out, please. I believe that Barney told Al Paquette what happened that night and sent Al to the window here to watch out for Manion - while he stood by by one of his gun racks - waiting. Manion came in and fired almost the moment he entered the door and that first shot went right through Barney's heart, All I want is for you to try and persuade Al to come into court as a defense witness and tell the court what Barney told him - that he had raped and assaulted Mrs, Manion,

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Al wouldn't conceal that. Why wouldn't he tell it if it were true?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Everybody loves something or someone, Me, I love fishing and an old guy named Parnell, Manion loves his freedom ~ he'd like more of it, Barney loved you -= and maybe so does Al, I wouldn't blame him, He doesn't want youto | know the truth about Barney... that he '..gould'be'brutal'and dangerous, But if you ask Al <= straight out ~- She stares at Paul for a long time -- then calls:

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Al. Behind the bar, darkly watching the table where Mary and Paquette motions for a waitress to take over the bar and slowly to Mary. . (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: l4l-a,

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: (continues) Al, Mr. Biegler knows Barney was my father and he thinks you know something about the night my father was killed - something you won't tell.

dialogues.speaker: AL
dialogues.text: Lawyer, I told you once and I'll tell you again, No questions, no answers,

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Wait, Al, Did my father rape Mrs. Manion?

dialogues.speaker: AL \
dialogues.text: Barney wouldn't hurt a woman, He was a good guy - just like you thought.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: is there any reason you wouldn't tell me the truth, Al?

dialogues.speaker: AL
dialogues.text: (a queer pause) What reason?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Anything else, Mr. Biegler?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (rises = puts on the wet hat) I'll leave a.pass for you and Al at the trial, You might like to watch Lt, Manion get convicted,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He goes to the decor. . » AL : se You going to spread it around about Mary being Barney's kid?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (he's tired) No, Al, I'm not going to spread it around, Good night, Miss Pilant. He goes, Paquette moves to the window, looking after Paul disappears into the wet night. Mary remains at the table and thoughtful,

dialogues.speaker: COURTROOM
dialogues.text: Manion is on the stand, He is cool, straight-forward, at alert. Paul is questioning,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now let's get at that rosary thing, It has been testified that your wife swore to you on a rosary that she had been raped by Barney Quill, Did you ask her to swear on a rosary?

dialogues.speaker: MANION
dialogues.text: My wife was hysterical and wasn't making much sense, I thought if I asked her to take an oath on the rosary it might serve to calm her and make her think clearly.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Did the rosary help?

dialogues.speaker: MANION
dialogues.text: ° She was able to tell me in detail what had happened,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Now go on from here, What did you do then, Lieutenant ?

dialogues.speaker: MANION
dialogues.text: I had her lie on the bed and I got some cold cloths for her head and == oh yes, I gave her a drink of brandy, After a while she became quiet and seemed to goto sleep, Then I went to the closet and got my gun and loaded it,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Was it in your mind to kill Barney Quill? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: oO No.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Why did you get your gun and load it?

dialogues.speaker: MANION
dialogues.text: I knew I had to go to Quill's bar and I thought I might need it,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: MANION
dialogues.text: I knew Mr, Quill kept guns behind the i bar. I was afraid he might shoot me.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: -——-—.-___Might shoot you if you did what? What were you going to do?

dialogues.speaker: ' MANION
dialogues.text: I'm not sure. I remember I had some idea of finding him and holding him while I called the police,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: wy) But Mr. Lemon right in the tourist park was a deputy sheriff, Why didn't you get him to go with you?

dialogues.speaker: MANION
dialogues.text: I don't know why I didn't think of Mr. Lemon. Maybe because he always seemed to be nothing except the old caretaker of the park. Maybe because I wasn't thinking too clearly about anything -- except finding Barney Quill,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why didn't you go to the telephone and call the State Police before you went to the bar?

dialogues.speaker: MANION
dialogues.text: I don't know why. I was in sort of a daze, It was an awful thing to see what had been done to my wife,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: You say you were ina daze. When you got to the bar -- did you see that @ the bar was crowded? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MANION
dialogues.text: I don't remember anyone at that bar except Barney Quill, He was the only person I saw.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: What was he doing? MANION . I think he was just standing behind the bar.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Did he make a threatening move to reach for a gun?

dialogues.speaker: MANION
dialogues.text: I don't know, He might have, but I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Now since you went there to find him and hold him for the police, why did you shoot him?

dialogues.speaker: MANION
dialogues.text: Idon't remember shooting him,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: As. you left the bar, do you remember Alphonse Paquette stopping you and saying you'd better not run away from this? -- and your reply -- 'Do you want some, too, Buster?!

dialogues.speaker: MANION
dialogues.text: I seem to have a vague recollection of someone speaking to me but I don't remember what I said or what ‘was said to me,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Do you remember going home?

dialogues.speaker: MANION
dialogues.text: Not clearly.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: When did you realize you had shot Quill?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was getting a drink of water. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: MANION (cont'd) I remember my throat was so dry that it hurt. When I put the glass down I saw the gun on the kitchen sink beside the tap. I noticed the gun was empty. Paul takes the Luger from the table, hands it to Manion,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Will you please show the Court how you knew the gun was empty?

dialogues.speaker: MANION
dialogues.text: (demonstrating on the Luger) This gadget here. When it sticks up you know the last round has been fired,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Lieutenant Manion, on the night of the shooting did you love your wife?

dialogues.speaker: MANION
dialogues.text: Yessir, PAUL — Do you still love her?

dialogues.speaker: MANION
dialogues.text: Very much, Laura's face as she watches Manion is without emotion.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Your witness, Mr. Dancer, Dancer comes over slowly, twisting a ring on his finger, smiling at Manion, Manion faces him calmly.

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: Lieutenant Manion, how many men have you killed?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Now wait a minute. Your honor, a man's war record -- in Lieutenant Manion's case a great record -- certainly should not be used against him, - (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: Your honor, I'm as patriotic as the next man but the simple truth is that war can condition a man to killing other men, I only wish to determine how conditioned the lieutenant may be to the use of fire arms on another human being,

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE WEAVER
dialogues.text: I don't approve of the question, Mr. Biegler, but on the other hand I don't see how I can turn it down, Let's see what Mr. Dancer is going to do with the information. Take the answer,

dialogues.speaker: MANION
dialogues.text: I know I killed at least four men in Korea, Three of ther with a hand grenade and one with my service automatic. I may have killed others. A soldier doesn't always know,

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: Now Lieutenant, in these acts of killing, did you ever have a lapse of memory such as you had when you killed Barney Quill?

dialogues.speaker: MANION
dialogues.text: No sir,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you ever have a lapse of memory during battle?

dialogues.speaker: MANION
dialogues.text: No sir. .

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: Were you ever submitted to a constant barrage, constantly in a sweat for many hours, constantly under attack or attacking?

dialogues.speaker: MANION
dialogues.text: : Many times.

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: Were you ever treated for shell shock, battle fatigue or any war neurosis or psychosis?
(CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ' MANION
dialogues.text: No,

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: Did you ever experience an unusual mental state during the war?

dialogues.speaker: MANION
dialogues.text: I do remember having one great urge.

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: What was that?

dialogues.speaker: MANION
dialogues.text: To get the hell out and go home, The laughter comes,

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE WEAVER
dialogues.text: (rapping for silence) The defendant will confine himself to the seriousness of his present situation,

dialogues.speaker: MANION
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, your honor, Dancer has taken the joke with good humor,

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: I sympathize with the Lieutenant. I expect he has the same feeling about being in jail, The main point here, Lieutenant, is that in all of your war service you had no record of mental disturbance? You were at all times in possession of your faculties? .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yessir. That's right.

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: No more questions,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: No re-direct, your honor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A BUZZ goes through the courtroom, Was this all that Danc was going todo? Paul, puzzled, watches Dancer return to t prosecution table.
(CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE WEAVER
dialogues.text: You may step down, Lieutenant, Call your next witness please.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: We call Laura Manion to the stand, Manion hurries to sit beside Paul.

dialogues.speaker: MANION
dialogues.text: (whispering) I thought you said he'd skin me alive,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Wait. Nervously, hands gripping her purse, Laura is sworn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary Pilant enters the Courthouse, comes into the rotunda hesitates with uncertainty at the bottom of the stairs, t

dialogues.speaker: INT, COURTROOM
dialogues.text: Laura is on the stand, Paul questioning, As Laura talks, back of the courtroom Mary enters. The Deputy inside the shows her to a space on a spectator bench, Paul sees Mary enter, follows her with curious eyes as she is seated.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: How long after you told your husband what had happened did he leave the trailer?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: 1 don't know exactly, Everything was kind of fuzzy. Iwas faint and I lay © ‘down on the bed. and he sat beside ‘me. I vaguely remember his getting up and going out, I remember wondering if he was going for a doctor and then he came back in, It seemed just a few seconds but it must've been longer -- I must've gone to sleep. When he came back in and sat on the bed he had a gun in his hand and I said, ‘What are you going to do?' And he said, 'I think I've already done it. I think I've killed Barney Quill. ' (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: © a

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you sure he didn't say, 'I've killed Barney Quill?!

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: No. I remember distinctly. ‘I think I've killed Barney Quill, ! :

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Now what did you do?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: I put my arms around him and began to cry and I said, ‘You'd better go to Mr. Lemon! and my husband said, ‘I forgot about that, '

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: What did he mean =- forgot about what?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: He meant he'd forgotten that Mr, Lemon was a Deputy Sheriff and he said, 'Yes, I'll go turn myself in to Mr. Lemon, !

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Your honor, I have no other direct questions at this time, But since I'm sure the credulity of the Court has been strained about the part the little dog played on this night, I should like a few minutes to show the Court this remarkable little animal,

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE WEAVER
dialogues.text: Do the People have objections?

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: I know if we raise an objection Mr, Biegler will declare that we are haters of all small furry animals. And I must also admit I'm curious to see this dog which leads the way home for ladies in distress,

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE WEAVER
dialogues.text: (wearily) A créature that cannot talk will be a welcome relief, Produce the dog. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (turns to the rear of the courtroom) Will the Deputy bring in the dog please? The Deputy Sheriff at the main doors goes outside for a m .Paul moves his gaze to Mary. Their eyes meet and she loo away. The Deputy re-enters, carrying a traveling case for

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (continues) Just let the dog out there, The Deputy puts the case on the floor and opens its door. bounces out,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (continues; calling) Come on, Muff, The little dog scampers down the aisle and bounds into Pa

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (continues) Now I'll ask Mrs. Manion to give the dog a flashlight. Laura steps down from the box and takes a small flashligh her purse, Paul places the dog on the floor and the dog r Laura, romping in delight as he sees the flashlight.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Hello, baby -- hello, sweetie. Does sweetie want the flashlight?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I'd like the Court to notice that the dog will turn the light on, Laura puts.the flashlight on the floor and: Muff paws at it in his mouth, his teeth over the switch, The light goe A ripple of amusement and approval from the jury which sw to laughter as. Muff runs to Dancer with the light, stand his paws on Dancer's leg, Judge Weaver raps for silence,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (continues) It's easy to see that Muff doesn't know who his enemies are. Another laugh from the courtroom, Judge Weaver raps again (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE WEAVER
dialogues.text: Remove the dog please. Witness will return to the stand. Sheriff Battisfore gathers up Muff, returns him to the De Laura steps into the witness box and Dancer moves in for cross~examination, Dancer smiles and makes a little bow.

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: Mrs. Manion, may I compliment you on your well-trained pet. Laura smiles, a timid grateful smile -- somewhat disarmed

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: (continues) May I also say I'm pleased to see you are not today hiding your lovely hair under a hat,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Your honor, is the assistant-attorney general from Lansing pitching woo or is he going to cross~examine. A laugh from the courtroom which does not disturb the imperturbable Dancer. JUDGE WEAVE. (rapping) . Let's get on with it,

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: Mrs. Manion, what was your occupation before you were married to the Lieutenant?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Housewife.

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: You mean you were married before?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Yes, once,

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: I suppose your first husband died?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: Did you divorce your first husband for Lieutenant Manion? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Your honor, if counsel wants to know the grounds for Mrs. Manion's divorce -- let him ask that question,

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: What were the grounds for divorce, Mrs. Manion? -

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Mental cruelty.

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: Naturally. How long was it after your divorce that you married Lieutenant

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Manion?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: I'm -- I'm not sure, soo

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (quickly) May I refresh the witness's memory for Mr. Dancer?

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: By all means, PAUL . I believe she told me that they were married three days after the divorce. Laura and Paul have locked eyes, He is deliberately showi her that she must not be evasive. Dancer looks from one t the other, grasping the situation,

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: Thank you, Mr. Biegler, Is that correct, Mrs. Manion? :

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: {a murmur) Yes,

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: Then unless yours was a whirlwind courtship you must have known Lieutenant Manion before your divorce. Did you?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Yes,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: On the jury a couple of women exchange significant looks.

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: What is your religious affiliation, Mrs. Manion?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: I'm a Catholic.

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: A Catholic in good standing?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Well, no -= the divorce -= you know.

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: You mean you have been ex-communicated because of the divorce?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Yes,

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: Mrs, Manion, wouldn't you say that a Catholic who can blithely ignore a cardinal rule of her church can also easily ignore an oath taken on one of its artifacts -- say an oath taken on a rosary?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: I don't think that's true.

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: But wouldn't you think there'd be some doubt about the integrity of such a person? I don't know. All I know is the rosary means something to me.

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: (smoothly) I see. Well, I'll pass on to something else, The ANGLE of the CAMERA is such that we can see that Danc has blocked Paul's view.of Laura, Paul moves to another c at the counsel table. As Dancer continues he steps around obscure Paul's view of Laura. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: . DANCER
dialogues.text: OQ Mrs, Manion, you've testified that your husband was late in coming home from his work on the night of the shooting, Were you angry about his being late?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: I guess I was a little put out.

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: Did you have an argument?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Not much, A little.

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: When you left the trailer to go to the tan did your _husband_know that-you were leaving?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: He was asleep,

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: Was part of your reason for going to the Inn without his knowledge because you were vexed?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Well, I'd been ironing all day and -- yes, I guess that's true.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Your honor, may the record show that counsel has deliberately cut off my view of the witness.

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: - . (smoothly) : I'm sorry, Mr. Biegler. ‘1 wouldn't want to interfere with your signals to Mrs. Manion,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (angrily) I further object to the implication that I'm signaling the witness. This is the shabbiest courtroom trick I've ever seen.

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: You haven't lived, Mr. Biegler.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ©) Your honor, I ask that the Court rule on my objection. .

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE WEAVER
dialogues.text: Mr. Dancer, will you be careful not to place yourself between Mr. Biegler and his witness?

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: Of course, your honor, (he moves out of the way) Anything else, Mr. Biegler?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: You do it once again and I'll punt you all the way out into the middle of Lake Superior.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE WEAVER
dialogues.text: (banging his gavel) This back~biting has got to stop. The next one of you that speaks out of turn is going to have me to deal with. Now get on with the cross-examination., . O The courtroom becomes quiet and Dancer continues.

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: Would you have-gone to the Inn if your husband had been awake?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: He would probably have gone with me.

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: But would you have gone alone?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Well, not if he didn't want me to,

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: Would he have not wanted you to?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: I'm not sure, I don't know how to answer that.

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: Had you ever gone before to the Thunder Bay Inn or elsewhere in Thunder Bay at night -- alone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: C) Yes. Sometimes,

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: Did your husband know you were going?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Not always, He goes to sleep early and sometimes I'm restless,

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: Where did you go on these occasions?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: I took a walk by the lake or I went to the bingo place or maybe to the e 1

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: Did you ever go to meet another man?

dialogues.speaker: ' LAURA
dialogues.text: ' No. NoI didnot, I never did that,

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: \ Do you mean to say, Mrs. Manion, ch that a lovely woman like yourself, 7) attractive to men, lonely, restless -- that you never...

dialogues.speaker: _ PAUL
