dialogues.text: Objection, your honor. ‘ The witness answered the question about other 1 men. Counsel is now making a veiled suggestion for the jury.

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: I withdraw the question. Now Mrs. Manion, on.these occasional excursions into the night, did you always go and return alone?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Of course,

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: But Mrs. Manion, you testified that you got into Barney Quill's car because you were afraid to go home alone. Why were you so frightened on that particular night?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ‘ LAURA I said it was because he told me that bears had been seen around,

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: Was this the first time you'd heard of bears coming around Thunder Bay to pick up scraps?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: Had you seen the bears around before?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Yes,

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: Then this was just the first time that wee ee you were afraid of them?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: No, I was always afraid of them.

dialogues.speaker: . DANCER
dialogues.text: Then this was the first time you were enough afraid to allow a man to take you home from one of your evening prowls?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Objection, The use of the word ‘prowl! is intended to mislead the jury.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE WEAVER
dialogues.text: Sustained, Ask the question again, Mr. Dancer. :

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, Mrs, Manion, I didn't mean to imply that you were a huntress -~ so let's say, "evening walks," Was this the first time you were frightened enough to let someone take you home from an evening walk?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: But it wasn't just that -- it was a sort of -- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: Come, Mrs, Manion, you should be able to tell us that straight off. It's a simple enough question. Laura is pale and shaky. She dabs at her lips and forehea her handkerchief, .

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Your honor, how can the witness answer straight off if the counsel interrupts her answer?!

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE WEAVER
dialogues.text: Witness seemed rather slow to me, Mr. Biegler. However, I'd let the witness complete a statement if she can, Mr, Dancer, before you interrupt,

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: Of course, your honor, In any case, Mr. Biegler's objection has given Mrs. Manion sufficient time to think of an answer to my question, You've thought of one, haven't you, Mrs, Manion?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: What I was going to say is that I didn't want to offend Mr. Quill by making him think I was afraid of him or didn't like him. He had been very pleasant to my husband and me when we were in his bar.

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: That's very good, Mrs. Manion, very good indeed,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Your honor...

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE WEAVER
dialogues.text: Attorney for the People will save his comments for the arguments,

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: I will ask you this question, Mrs. Manion... (slowly) .+. Was this the first time you had been in Barney Quill's car at night? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Laura's nervous gaze is quickly fastened on Manion, frigh Q of his tight lips and cold eyes,

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE WEAVER
dialogues.text: Mrs. Manion, did you hear the question?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: (looking down at her hands) Yes, Iheard, Yes, it was the first time, Dancer looks at the jury. Their attention is hard on Laur faces a study of the questions in their minds -- One man frowns with puzzlement -- another's lips are purs another is scratching his chin, a woman's head is turned askance, her ear to the witness -- another peers out over -- spectacles,
‘ Would you raise your voice a little, Mrs. Manion? | ‘ LAURA Cs I said it was the first time,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: bleak, eyes glittering cruelly.

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: (changing pace) Now Mrs, Manion, I'm quite concerned about the lost panties. Would. you describe this article of clothing to the Court?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: They were nylon and had lace up the side. There was a label of the shop where I bought them -- Smartshop in Phoenix, Arizona.

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: What was the color of the panties? eg LAURA ‘ I believe white, (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CD You believe?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Ihave white and pink -- they may have been pink,

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: You're not sure? Haven't you checked your lingerie wardrobe to see which pair of panties is missing?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: When your husband came home from work and you had this little spat, were you already dressed to go out?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: No. ae

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: When did you dress?

dialogues.speaker: . LAURA
dialogues.text: ' After dinner, After he was asleep. ro) DANCER It has been stated here that you were , bare-legged in the bar. Is that true?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: In your anger at your husband and your haste to get out of the trailer, perhaps you didn't put on any panties, either?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Objection, Witness has already testified as to what she was wearing. —_ Sustained,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her face pale and composed, but her eyes are wide with a fear, or knowledge,

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: Do you always wear panties, Mrs, Manion? Laura glances helplessly at Paul,

dialogues.speaker: . PAUL
dialogues.text: Your honor, I object to this line of questioning. It's immaterial what Mrs. Manion does all the time, On the night she was attacked she was wearing panties. That's all we're concerned with,

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: Your honor, Mrs. Manion seems uncertain about what kind of panties she was wearing and since these panties have not been found I submit that it's possible she wasn't wearing any and has forgotten. That's what I'm trying to get at.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE WEAVER
dialogues.text: Take the answer, Mrs. Manion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: De you always wear panties?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: (on the verge of tears) No.

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: On what occasions don't you wear them? -- when you go out alone at night?

dialogues.speaker: . PAUL
dialogues.text: (angry) Your honor, we've been had, He says he's after one thing and he goes for another.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE WEAVER
dialogues.text: I'll sustain the objection. Strike the last two questions and Mrs. Manion's answer, Now get off the subject of panties, Mr. Dancer, You've done enough damage.

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: Yes, your honor. Is your husband a jealous man, Mrs. Manion?
(CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Maida glances quickly at Paul who is terribly still, held suspense,

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Well, he -- he loves me.

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: I'm sure of that. But is he excessively jealous?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: How can the witness answer that, your honor? What is the norm o: jealousy? .

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE WEAVER
dialogues.text: Can you put your question in another way, Mr. Dancer?

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: Has your husband ever struck you in a jealous rage, Mrs. Manion?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Your honor, I think Mr, Dancer is fishing. What is the relevancy of this question?

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: Your honor, the shoe is squeezing Mr. Biegler's foot. In his own words, this is not a high school debate, it's a cross-examination in a murder trial.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE WEAVER
dialogues.text: Can you nail your questions down a little more, Mr. Dancer?

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: I believe so, your honor. Mrs. Manion, did you ever go out socially in Thunder Bay?

dialogues.speaker: ' LAURA
dialogues.text: Yes, a few times,

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: When your husband's outfit moved into Thunder Bay, didn't Barney Quill throw a cocktail party for the officers and their wives ? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: cP

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: Did your husband strike a young second Lieutenant at the party?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: There was a little scuffle, It wasn't much,

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: What was it about?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: I'm not sure I remember.

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: Were you too drunk to remember?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: No, Iwas not. I think the Lieutenant was cutting in too much when I was dancing with my husband,

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: And shortly afterward didn't your husband on the veranda of the Inn slap you hard enough that you fell against the wall?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: He was drinking,

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: Wasn't this a jealous rage?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: Do you remember why he struck you?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Well, yes.

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: Wasn't he enraged at you because he thought you had encouraged this young lieutenant?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: He might have thought so. 162. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Paul's face frightened,

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: Mrs. Manion, there are witnesses to this whole affair. I'll ask you again -- wasn't this jealous rage?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: I suppose it could be called that,

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: (boring in) Now I'll ask you -- on the night of the shoating, what did you swear, what oath did you take on the rosary?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: It was about Barney Quill raping me.

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: Why did you swear on the rosary that he had raped you?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: For the reason that my husband said -- Iwas hysterical,

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: That was the reason he gave for asking you to swear, What was your reason for swearing?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: (blindly) So he'd believe me. is anxious. Dancer's getting close. Laura is

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: Why, shouldn't he believe you?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Objection, your honor, The reason for the use of the rosary has been established, These questions are immaterial,

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE WEAVER
dialogues.text: No, I think I'll take the answer, Mr. Biegler.

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: Iask you again, Mrs, Manion -- why shouldn't he believe you? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Q . LAURA
dialogues.text: I guess -- I guess because I wasn't making sense,

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: Did he think you were lying about a thing like that?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Objection, Lieutenant Manion has already testified as to what he thought.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE WEAVER
dialogues.text: Sustained,

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: (suddenly) Did your husband strike you that night? Laura is unable to answer -- her lips moving without soun

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: Did he hit you that night?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: He -- when -- he might have slapped oO me because I was hysterical,

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: And didn't you swear to a lie to keep him from hitting you again?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: No -- I didn't -- I did not.

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: (driving) Hadn't he already beat you up at the gate when he caught you coming home from a trip dows lovers' lane with Barney Quill?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul is on his feet before Dancer is done, his voice comi Dancer's, Dancer raising his voice to complete the questi

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (shouting) Objection, The witness has testified that she was beaten by Barney Quill, The courtroom is rumbling. Judge Weaver raps for silence. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: lol 165.

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: No more questions. Laura bursts into tears,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I think the witness has had enough, your honor,

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE WEAVER
dialogues.text: The witness may step down, We will recess until after lunch, He raps his gavel and steps down from the bench toward hi In the flash of photographers' bulbs and hubbub in the co comes down from the stand. Manion is quickly beside her, around her.

dialogues.speaker: MANION
dialogues.text: (whispering) I'm sorry, baby. Maida has come into the enclosure,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Maida, take Mrs, Manion to the house and let her rest, Manion kisses Laura on the cheek,

dialogues.speaker: MANION
dialogues.text: It's all over now.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Did I do all right?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: You did fine,

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF
dialogues.text: Come on, Lieutenant. Let's see what Sulo has for us. Manion goes with the Sheriff, Laura with Maida through th the lawyers' conference room. Paul gets his hat from the starts up the aisle to the main doors of the courtroom, T is emptying and Mary is isolated among the empty benches. moves toward her. Nervously she rises, and avoiding him, to join the throng leaving the courtroom, Paul holds, loo her with curiosity.

dialogues.speaker: EXT, IRON CITY RAILROAD STATION
dialogues.text: Parnell is on the platform as the train is pulling in, He a little and hobbling, When the train stops, a woman and get off, a YOUNG MAN with a stubby nose and a crewcut get an elderly couple follows and then a middle-aged DISTINGU LOOKING MAN with a neat, greying moustache and wearing a hat, Parnell's face lights up and he approaches the disti middle-aged man,

dialogues.speaker: PARNELL
dialogues.text: Dr. Smith?

dialogues.speaker: DISTINGUISHED MAN
dialogues.text: Pardon?

dialogues.speaker: PARNELL
dialogues.text: I've come to meet you -- My name is --

dialogues.speaker: DISTINGUISHED MAN
dialogues.text: a (cutting him off) I'm sorry. You made a mistake, ‘The man moves on and the kid with the stubby nose and th approaches Parnell,

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: Maybe I'm the one you're looking for. Are you Mr. Biegler?

dialogues.speaker: PARNELL
dialogues.text: (in disbelief) No, No, I'm his associate in the case, Don't tell me you're Dr. Smith?

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: That's me.

dialogues.speaker: PARNELL
dialogues.text: {in disbelief) The -- army -- psychiatrist?

dialogues.speaker: " SMITH
dialogues.text: Maybe you expected me to be in uniform?

dialogues.speaker: PARNELL
dialogues.text: No -- sure -- well, I didn't expect anybody so young.

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: I'm forty.

dialogues.speaker: PARNELL
dialogues.text: I sort of hoped you'd have a beard and wear a monocle, (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: Oh, I see, He takes out a pair of heavy horn-rimmed glasses and slip

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: (continues; grinning) That better?

dialogues.speaker: PARNELL
dialogues.text: + (grins) It helps. - Well, we'd better shove along. Parnell takes the doctor's small overnight bag and they w down the platform,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Smith, in his horn-rimmed glasses, is on the stand, P with Maida on the spectator's bench behind defense table, interrogating. . PAUL” Doctor, have you formed an opinion, as to Frederick Manion's emotional disorganization at the time he killed Barney Quill?

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: Ihave,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: What is that opinion?

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: He was temporarily insane at the time of the shooting,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: At the time of the shooting do you believe that he was able to distinguish right from wrong?

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: He may or may not have been. It doesn't make too much difference, (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Now doctor, as clearly as you can, will you explain Frederick Manion's temporary insanity? SMITH. It is known as dissociative reaction, A psychic shock which creates an almost overwhelming tension which the person in shock must alleviate. In Lieutenant Manion's case, a soldier, it is natural that he would turn to action. Only direct simple action against Barney Quill would relieve this unbearable tension. This is not too uncommon, For example in combat -- in war I mean -- some of the more remarkable heroics take place in this state of mind. Soldiers who have performed fantastically brave acts are frequently unable to recall having performed those acts because they were at the time in the grip of dissociative reaction,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Is there another name for dissociative reaction, one we are more likely to recognize?

dialogues.speaker: SMITH -
dialogues.text: Yes, It has been known as ‘irresistible impulse, ' Paul glances toward the prosecution table, Dancer and Mit in a whispering huddle.. Paul half-grins, .

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Now doctor, a man in the. grip of irresistible impulse.-- would he be likely to go to a neighbor for advice, would he call the police to come to his aid?

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: Completely incompatible, In this trance-like state he would be unable to think of anything except the relief of this massive tension.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: But our man was able to think of taking out a gun and loading it before he set off to find Barney Quill, (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PAUL (cont'd) He testified that he got the gun because he was afraid Quill would shoot him, If he was in a trance~like state, how do you explain this?

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: That was his conscious mind working -- but if no gun had been available he would have gone anyway -- bare-handed =- he would have walked into the mouth of acannon, It's important to understand that the very essence of his manhood was at stake, Nothing short of oblivion or death could have prevailed against his overpowering need,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Would this tension interfere with his physical ability? -- say his ability to accurately fire a gun?

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: It probably would have heightened his ability,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: How would a man look when in the grip of dissociative reaction? SMITH . He might appear to be deadly calm -- fiercely deliberate.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Gould you describe his behavior as being like a mailman delivering the mail? .

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: That's not bad. Like a mailman, he would have one job to do and he would do it.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Would a man in this state be apt to converse with other men?

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: It's possible, although he wouldn't likely initiate conversation,

dialogues.speaker: . PAUL
dialogues.text: QO Do you mean that if someone stopped him and spoke to him he might answer but he wouldn't be likely to speak first?

dialogues.speaker: . SMITH
dialogues.text: . Not likely --

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Your witness. Dancer rises. During his first few questions Paul is surv the courtroom -- then bends to Maida and whispers -~

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Can you spot Mary Pilant?

dialogues.speaker: MAIDA
dialogues.text: She didn't come back after lunch. You'd better give up on that one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Between Dancer and Smith,.,

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: Doctor, did you find any psychosis in Frederick Manion? © SMITH ~ I did not.

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: Any neuroses?

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: I found no history of neuroses,

dialogues.speaker: . DANCER
dialogues.text: Did you find any history of delusion?

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: None.

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: Loss of memory?

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: Not before this instance,

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: How about hallucinations?

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: DANCER © Any history of conversion hysteria?

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: Well, irresistible impulse embraces what has been called conversion hysteria,

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: In common language isn't conversion hysteria also known as a fit of temper?

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: I know of no reputable psychiatrist who would so describe it,

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: But a layman might call it that?

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: Probably, yes.

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: Isn't that what really happened? In a fit of temper -- in a fit of rage, the Lieutenant walked over and shot Barney Quill,

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: ‘No, not in my opinion, That is not what happened,

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: Doctor, you stated that the Lieutenant might or might not have been able to distinguish right from wrong == but that it didn't make much difference. Am I right? Is that what you said?

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: Approximately -- yes,

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: Did you mean that at the time of the shooting he could have known the difference between right and wrong?

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: He might have, yes. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: Doctor Smith, if the defendant could have known what he was doing and could have known that it was wrong, how can you come here and testify that he was legally insane?

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: I'm not saying he was legally insane. I'm a doctor, not a lawyer. I'm saying that in his mental condition it would not have made any difference whether he knew right from wrong =- he would still have shot Quill, He could not have prevented himself from doing so.

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: In other words, what he did he did willfully and in anger? wo es SMITH The words ‘anger! and 'wiliful' are an immense simplification of a very complicated mental condition, I repeat, Lieutenant Manion was temporarily insane,

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: Are you willing to rest your testimony in this case on this opinion?

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: lam

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: (looking at Paul, puzzled) Your honor,’ I-would like.to ask for a short recess, The attorneys for the People would like to meet with Mr. Biegler and the Court in chambers,

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE WEAVER
dialogues.text: Mr, Biegler?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Glad to oblige, your honor.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE WEAVER
dialogues.text: Court will stand in recess for ten minutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He steps down from the bench toward his chambers, followe Paul, Dancer and Mitch, Paul is carrying the lawbook whic has kept on the defense table, the same book in which he the fishing lure earlier in the case,

dialogues.speaker: INT, JUDGE'S CHAMBERS
dialogues.text: The Judge enters, followed by Paul, Dancer and Mitch. Jud goes directly to his desk, seizes his pipe and begins to

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE WEAVER
dialogues.text: One day I'm going to horrify tradition and lay a blue pall of good Virginia burley on that hallowed precinct out there, (he gets his pipe lighted) All right, Mr. Dancer,

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: I thought perhaps in view of Dr. Smith's testimony the defense might like to change their plea.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Change it to what?

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: To guilty, of course.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: No, we'll still go for broke.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Hell, Polly, you know a guy's not considered legally nuts in Michigan unless he didn't know right from wrong. Why don't you come on and end this thing?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (placing his lawbook before Judge Weaver) Jagger would you open that to page —

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE WEAVER
dialogues.text: It appears to be a lawbook, Mr. Lodwick. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Q . Judge Weaver pulls down his glasses, opens the book t page -~- glances at Paul expectantly, and picks the red f fishing lure off the open page. .

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (reaching for the lure) Oh -- sorry, Your Honor. I make those things to help me think sometimes.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE WEAVER
dialogues.text: (inspects the lure) For perch?

dialogues.speaker: -PAUL
dialogues.text: No, sir -- frogs.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: (impatiently) What case is he citing, Judge?

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE WEAVER
dialogues.text: {absorbed by lure) We gig frogs in my part of the country.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: oy (demonstrating mS as he talks) Yessir, up here, too - but this is a new wrinkle I'm going totry. They do it in the bayous down south. You use a long pole with a ten pound line and sort of drift along a high bank in the boat. Mitch turns away in impatient disgust; Dancer is amused.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (continues) : You see a big bull sitting back ina crevice, You swing this out and kind of let it float in front of him -- and POP -~ that old tongue of his will snap out and you got frog legs for supper.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE WEAVER
dialogues.text: I'll be darned.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Keep it and try it sometime. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: XD JUDGE WEAVER
dialogues.text: Thanks. I will, ~ . (he's suddenly reminded of the 4 business at hand) Oh <- yes, page 106 I believe you said, He bends over the book and reads slowly. Mitch comes back desk and hovers over the Judge.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE WEAVER
dialogues.text: (continues; finally) Hummp!

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: What is it, Your Honor?

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE WEAVER
dialogues.text: Precedent. People versus Durfee -~ year 1886. Would you like to read it, Mr. Dancer?

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: No, Your Honor. We're hooked -- like the frog. aa

dialogues.speaker: INT, COURTROOM
dialogues.text: DR, W. GREGORY HARCOURT is being sworn. Now he takes the witness stand, Dancer rises to examine, .

dialogues.speaker: . DANCER
dialogues.text: Dr. Harcourt, where did you receive your university training?

dialogues.speaker: HARCOURT
dialogues.text: Johns Hopkins in Baltimore, Maryland.

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: When were you admitted to the practice of medicine ?

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: Since that time have you specialized in any particular field of medicine? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HARCOURT
dialogues.text: Ihave -- the field of psychiatry.

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: Where do you practice now?

dialogues.speaker: HARCOURT
dialogues.text: Iam the medical superintendent of the Bonder State Hospital for the insane, Iam also psychiatric examiner for the Veterans! Administration,

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: Do you then feel that you have particular knowledge of the mental ills and problems of soldiers?

dialogues.speaker: HARCOURT
dialogues.text: I do.

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: It has been stated here that dissociative reaction or irresistible impulse is not uncommon among soldiers in combat. Do you agree with that statement?

dialogues.speaker: HARCOURT
dialogues.text: Ido, But not as it was put by Dr, Smith.

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: Where would you depart from Dr. Smith?

dialogues.speaker: HARCOURT
dialogues.text: Well, dissociative reaction is not something which comes out of the blue and disappears as quickly. It can only occur -- even among soldiers in combat -- if the individual has a psycho-neurotic condition of long standing. :

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Iobject, Your Honor. Is the Doctor stating a proved fact or an opinion? We are not dealing here with chicken pox or a sore throat but with the mysteries of the human mind. If the Doctor is giving his opinion it should be qualified as such.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE WEAVER
dialogues.text: Sustained. Do you want to straighten this out, Mr. Dancer? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: DANCER ‘ Your answer, Doctor, was of course your opinion, wasn't it?

dialogues.speaker: HARCOURT
dialogues.text: That goes without saying, doesn't it?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: No, it doesn't. Your Honor...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (patiently) Just say it is your opinion, Doctor, please.

dialogues.speaker: HARCOURT
dialogues.text: My answer was an opinion,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (sitting) All right.

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: Iam sure the jury has forgotten your answer by now, Doctor. Let's go back. Is it your opinion that dissociative reaction could not occur one time and one time only?

dialogues.speaker: HARCOURT
dialogues.text: Yes. There would have been repeated upsets of a dissociative nature.

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: It has been testified here that a psychiatric examination of the defendant showed no evidence of neuroses or history of dissociative reaction, You have heardit further testified here that the defendant's © behavior on the night of the shooting was cool and direct. As an observer do you remember this testimony?

dialogues.speaker: HARCOURT
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: From this have you formed an opinion about the defendant's sanity on the night of the shooting? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HARCOURT
dialogues.text: Yes. Iam of the opinion that he was in sufficient possession of his faculties so that he was not dominated by his unconscious mind.

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: In other words he was not in the grip of irresistible impulse?

dialogues.speaker: HARCOURT
dialogues.text: In my opinion he was not.

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: Your witness, Mr. Biegler.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Dr. Harcourt, psychiatry is an effort to probe into the dark undiscovered world of the mind -- and in there the world might well be round or it could be square -- your opinion could be wrong and Dr. Smith's opinion could be right, isn't that true?

dialogues.speaker: HARCOURT
dialogues.text: I'd be a poor Doctor if I didn't agree with that. But I believe my opinion to be right.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: And good Doctor that you are, you very carefully used the word believe, didn't you? :

dialogues.speaker: HARCOURT
dialogues.text: Yes, . PAUL . . Do you think you would have been less positive if you had examined the defendant as Dr. Smith did?

dialogues.speaker: HARCOURT
dialogues.text: I believe it would have helped to confirm my opinion.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: But isn't it possible it might have caused you to change this opinion?

dialogues.speaker: HARCOURT
dialogues.text: I don't believe so.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Doctor, did you ask to make an examination of the defendant?

dialogues.speaker: HARCOURT
dialogues.text: No sir.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Did the attorneys for the people petition for such an examination in your behalf?

dialogues.speaker: HARCOURT
dialogues.text: No sir.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: So your opinion boils down to a snap judgment, doesn't it?

dialogues.speaker: HARCOURT
dialogues.text: No. It is as careful a judgment as the circumstances permit.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Dr. Smith's opinion was made under better circumstances, wasn't it?

dialogues.speaker: HARCOURT
dialogues.text: If you mean that he was able to examine the man, yes.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Thank you, Doctor.

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: Doctor, upon what do you base your opinions?

dialogues.speaker: HARCOURT
dialogues.text: Upon the findings of other doctors and largely upon’my own years of study and analysis.

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: Are those many years?

dialogues.speaker: HARCOURT
dialogues.text: Over thirty years.

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: You were working in this field probably before Dr. Smith was born, weren't you?

dialogues.speaker: HARCOURT
dialogues.text: Yes. But that doesn't necessarily mean... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: (cutting him off) No more questions, that's ali.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Your Honor, we would like to hear the witness's answer. Counsel cut him off.

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: Witness has responded 'yes' to the question, .

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (grinning) But I think the Doctor was about to qualify that yes.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE WEAVER
dialogues.text: Get off of it, Mr. Biegler. Do you have any questions?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No questions, Your Honor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's all, Dr. Harcourt. Harcourt sits down, Dancer glares at him and huddles with

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE WEAVER
dialogues.text: (continues) Does the prosecutor have other rebuttal witnesses?

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: (whispering to Mitch) We're over a barrel. We'll have to-use him, Mitch.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: (rising) We call Duane Miller to the stand. Will the Sheriff please bring in the witness? Sheriff Battisfore goes into the lawyers' conference room is pale, seemingly stricken, his lips parted, his eyes af Sheriff comes from the conference room with Miller. The m a crooked smile, struts behind the Sheriff to the witness (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: i

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: {to Manion) What can he tell?

dialogues.speaker: MANION
dialogues.text: (nervous) + Nothing -- he can't tell anything. Dancer moves in for the interrogation, glancing at Manion observing the little drama at the defense table.

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: State your name.

dialogues.speaker: MILLER
dialogues.text: Duane Miller. Folks call me Duke.

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: Where do you presently reside, Mr. Miller?

dialogues.speaker: MILLER
dialogues.text: Across the alley, in the jail.

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: Do you know the defendant, Frederick Manion?

dialogues.speaker: MILLER
dialogues.text: Yessir. Sure.

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: How well do you know him?

dialogues.speaker: MILLER
dialogues.text: I got to know him the last few weeks. His cell's next to mine.

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: ‘Being neighbors, I suppose you frequently have had conversations with Lieutenant Manion?

dialogues.speaker: MILLER
dialogues.text: Yeah, we talk.

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: What was the last conversation you had with him?

dialogues.speaker: MILLER
dialogues.text: Well, except for a hello this morning, the last one was last night. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: Are you sure Mr. Miller, that the Lieutenant said, 'I've got it made -- BUSTER?! —

dialogues.speaker: MILLER
dialogues.text: That's what he said -- Buster.

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: Mr. Miller, did Lieutenant Manion say anything else?

dialogues.speaker: MILLER
dialogues.text: (grinning) Yessir. He said when he got out the first thing he was going to do was kick that bitch from here to kingdom come. CLOSE UP iis a of Laura, teeth set against her trembling lip.

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: To whom was he referring ?

dialogues.speaker: MILLER
dialogues.text: To.his wife.

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: Your witness. Paul surveys the jury as he rises. From his POV their fac set and sullen. — : eee 8 oe

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Mr. Miller, what are you in jail for?

dialogues.speaker: MILLER
dialogues.text: Arson. I copped out and I'm waiting for a sentence. In the b.g. the Guard from the main courtroom doors comes aisle, hands a note to Parnell. Parnell scans the note, s something to Maida, rises and hobbles quickly up the aisl the main doors. PAUL . How many other offenses have you committed? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: Did you discuss his trial last night?

dialogues.speaker: MILLER
dialogues.text: Some.

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: Tell the Court what Lieutenant Manion had to say about the trial.

dialogues.speaker: MILLER
dialogues.text: Well, I said are things looking up, Lieutenant? And he said, 'I got it made, Buster.' He said, 'I fooled my lawyer and I fooled that head shrinker and I'm going to fool that bunch of corn cobbers on the jury!'

dialogues.speaker: MANION
dialogues.text: (violently) You're a liar. You're a lousy, stinking liar!! The Judge raps for order. Paul draws Manion back into his

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I apologize for my client, Your Honor. Yet, his outburst is almost excusable since the prosecution has seen fit to put a felon on the stand to testify against an officer in the United States Army.

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: (angry) Your Honor, I don't know who is the worse offender -- Manion or his lawyer... JUDGE ‘WEAVER (patience lost) We're close to the end. In the name of heaven let's have peace and courtesy for these last few hours. Mr. Dancer, you will continue your interrogation without comment. Mr. Biegler will not perorate at every opportunity and the defendant will remain in his chair . and keep his mouth shut. He punctuates the end of his speech with a bang of his ga sits, humbly. Dancer takes out his handkerchief and dabs forehead. Manion, white and furious, sinks down into his (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Q » MILLER 7 Huh? Oh -- well, I was in reform school when I was a kid. That's all,

dialogues.speaker: . PAUL
dialogues.text: Your honor, I would like to see this man's criminal record,

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE WEAVER
dialogues.text: Do you have the record, Mr. Lodwick?

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: (sheepishly) Yes sir, here it is. Mitch produces several cards clipped together. Paul strid prosecution table, takes the cards, flips through them.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Mr. Miller, this record shows you've been in prison six times in three different states. You've been in three times for arson, twice for assault with a deadly weapon, once for larceny. It also shows you've done short stretches in four city jails for the charges of indecent exposure, window peeping, perjury, and committing a public nuisance. Is this your true record?

dialogues.speaker: MILLER
dialogues.text: Well, them things never are right. Paul stalks back to the prosecution table, angrily tosses the table. Mitch is embarrassed, but Dancer is imperturba usual.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Mr, Miller, how did-you.get the ear of the prosecution in order to tell them about your conversation with Lieutenant Manion?

dialogues.speaker: MILLER
dialogues.text: The D. A. was taking us to his office...

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Taking who to his office?

dialogues.speaker: MILLER
dialogues.text: Us prisoners in the jail.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: He took you all at once or one at a time?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CV MILLER
dialogues.text: One at atime. Him and that other lawyer took us to his office and asked us questions about Lieutenant Manion.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Were you promised a lighter sentence if you would go on the witness stand?

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: The People object, Your Honor, to being...

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE WEAVER
dialogues.text: (snapping him off) Overruled. Take the answer.

dialogues.speaker: MILLER
dialogues.text: t wasn't promised anything.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Perhaps you just thought it might help your own troubles if you dreamed up a story that would please the D. A. ?

dialogues.speaker: . MILLER
dialogues.text: So I didn't dream up nothing.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: And you're sure that's what Lieutenant Manion said? ©

dialogues.speaker: MILLER
dialogues.text: Yep, I'm sure.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Just as sure as you were about your criminal. record?

dialogues.speaker: MILLER
dialogues.text: Well, I kind of flubbed that I guess.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (with great distaste) I don't feel I can dignify this creature with any more questions. He returns to beside Manion. Dancer smiles and bows to th

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: No further questions, Your Honor. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE WEAVER
dialogues.text: Take the witness away. Miller steps down grinning and is led away by Sheriff Bat

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE WEAVER
dialogues.text: (continues) Mr. Biegler, would you like to have a conference with your client? I can see that Miller was very much of a surprise.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: No, Your Honor, we ton't need a conference. I'll recall Lieutenant Manion to the stand right now. Manion goes to the stand.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (continue s) You've heard the testimony of this Miller. Is any part of it true?

dialogues.speaker: MANION
dialogues.text: None. . )

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (studying Manion for a moment) Lieutenant, do you have any idea why he might come in here with a tale like that ?

dialogues.speaker: MANION
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Have you ever talked with this man? ‘ MANION Yes.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: What did you talk about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing important. Certainly nothing about my personal life or feelings.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: That is all I wanted to know. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: Lieutenant Manion, have you ever had any sort of trouble with Miller?

dialogues.speaker: MANION
dialogues.text: Trouble? I don't know -- you mean an argument -- something like that?

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: Did you ever attack Miller -- physically attack Miller? Paul realizes Dancer has used Miller as bait to get Manio the stand. Manion locks to Paul for help.

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: Your attorney can't answer the question . for you, Lieutenant Manion. Did you ever physically attack Miller?

dialogues.speaker: MANION
dialogues.text: I don't think you could call it an attack. I pushed his head against the bars one day.

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: MANION
dialogues.text: He said something ugly about my wife.

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: Do you clearly remember pushing or bumping his head against the bars?

dialogues.speaker: MANION
dialogues.text: Sure. I just told you.

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: Then this was not dissociative reaction.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: The defendant is not qualified to answer that.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE WEAVER
dialogues.text: Sustained,

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: Lieutenant Manion, wasn't your action against Barney Quill much the same thing as your action against Miller or the Lieutenant you slapped at the cocktail party ~~ all done in the heat of anger, with a willful, conscious desire to hurt or kill? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MANION
dialogues.text: I don't remember my action against Quill,

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: How long had you known your wife was stepping out with Quill?

dialogues.speaker: MANION
dialogues.text: Inever knew anything like that. I trust my wife.

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: You just occasionally beat her up for the fun of it, I suppose?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: _. (desperately) There has been nothing established to permit a question like that. He keeps trying to insinuate without ever coming to the point, Let him ask the Lieutenant, did he ever beat his wife.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE WEAVER
dialogues.text: I will sustain the objection. Do you want to re-phrase your question, Mr. Dancer?

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: (pleased) No thank you, Your Honor. I've finished.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I'll ask it. Did you, Lieutenant Manion, ever beat your wife on the night of the shooting or any other time?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No sir. 7

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Is there any doubt in your mind that Barney Quill raped Mrs. Manion?

dialogues.speaker: MANION
dialogues.text: No sir,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: That's all. .

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: Nothing more. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: . JUDGE WEAVER
dialogues.text: Step down, Lieutenant.

dialogues.speaker: O
dialogues.text: Manion comes down to take his seat at the defense table u hard gaze.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: We walked into that one.

dialogues.speaker: MANION
dialogues.text: > I'm sorry. I should have told you about Miller. Are we hurt?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Bad. Parnell comes hobbling down the center aisle from the mai doors,

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE WEAVER
dialogues.text: (watching Parnell) Does the prosecution have any other rebuttal witnesses?

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: {watching Parnell) No, Your Honor. We have no other witnesses,

dialogues.speaker: Q
dialogues.text: Parnell bends over the railing, whispers to Paul,

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE WEAVER
dialogues.text: Does the defense have any rebuttal witnesses?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Your Honor, I know time is very pressing and I don't want to ask for a recess. But I would like to leave the courtroom for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE WEAVER
dialogues.text: Well, I suppose if it's important we can be at ease for a minute.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: This is highly irregular, Your Honor.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE WEAVER
dialogues.text: Mr. Lodwick, there is no reason, as the saying goes, to make a federal case out of this. You're excused, 5 Mr. Biegler. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Q . Paul and Parnell hurry up the aisle, their heads clos talking as they go, hastening through the main doors into All eyes in the courtroom remain on the doors. The silenc | tempered by a low mumble of conversation. A few moments Dancer glances at his wristwatch, shrugs his impatience t Judge Weaver takes out his watch, winds it, motions to Sh Battisfore to approach the bench.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE WEAVER
dialogues.text: {in undertone) Sheriff, will you see if Mr. Biegler's gone fishing? Sheriff Battisfore trots up the center aisle and disappea main doors. Almost immediately he returns, followed by Pa Parnell and Mary Pilant.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: _ (coming through the gate) Thank you very much, Your Honor. ’ Inow have a rebuttal witness. The defense calls Mary Pilant to the stand. eee

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: {as Mary approaches) 7) . Your Honor, we'd like to protest this affair, The noble defense attorney rushes out to a secret conference and now the last minute witness is being brought dramatically down the center aisle. The whole thing has obviously been rigged to unduly excite the jury. It's just another of Mr. Biegler's cornball tricks.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Your Honor, I don't blame Mr. Dancer , . for feeling put upon. I'm.just a humble . country lawyer, trying to do the best I can against this brilliant prosecutor from the big city of Lansing. The jury glowers at Dancer and he paces away angrily. Pau suppresses a grin, .

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE WEAVER
dialogues.text: (sighing gloomily) Swear the witness. Mary is sworn and takes the stand. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Where do you live, Miss Pilant? At the prosecution table Mitch leans to Dancer, says some Dancer nods at the information.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: At the Thunder Bay Inn in Thunder Bay.

dialogues.speaker: , PAUL
dialogues.text: How long have you lived there ?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: For two years.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: What is your occupation, Miss Pilant?

dialogues.speaker: MARY -
dialogues.text: I manage the Inn.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Was Barney Quill your employer?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Yes,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: How is the laundry handled in the Inn?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: It's chuted down into the laundry room,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Where is the chute located on the second floor?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Between room 42 and 43,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Who lives in these rooms?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I live in 42 and Mr. Quill lived in 43,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Would Mr. Quill, coming up from the lobby, have to pass the mouth of this chute on the way to his room? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: a

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Could he easily drop something into this chute as he passed by? .

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Yes,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Now in the laundry room, what is done with the laundry? .

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: The sheets and slips are sent out and the towels are put into a wash and dry machine there in the room.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: When are the towels checked?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: As they're taken from the wash and dry. :

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Do you check them?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Yes. That is part of my work.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Will you tell us what you found among these towels on the day after Mr. Quill was killed?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I found a pair of women's panties,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: What did you do with them?

dialogues.speaker: , MARY
dialogues.text: I threw them in the rag bin.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: When did you learn of the significance of these panties?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Here, this morning in the courtroom. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Did you then go home and get them from the rag bin?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: (opens her purse) Yes. She hands a folded pair of panties to Paul. PAUL . I offer this article of lingerie as Exhibit One for the defense. They're white, have lace up the side and are badly torn <= as if they had been ripped apart. by powerful hands. ‘The label reads, 'Smartshop - Phoenix, Arizona.!

dialogues.speaker: __,.. JUDGE WEAVER
dialogues.text: If there are no objections the exhibit will be received in evidence.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: That's all, Miss Pilant. At the prosecution table Dancer rises, cold and determine

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: Did you ever talk with Mr. Lodwick, the prosecuting attorney, about Quill's death?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Yes, he came to the hotel several times after Mr. Quill was killed, .

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: Did you tell Mr. Lodwick that you ‘didn't believe that Barney Quill raped - Mrs. Manion?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Yes, I told him that.

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: Now, Miss Pilant, did you ever talk to the defense attorney, Mr. Biegler? |

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: Was this also in connection with the shooting of Barney Quill? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: Did you tell him you didn't believe Quill had raped Mrs, Manion?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: How many times did you talk to Mr. Biegler?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Twice,

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: When was the last time?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Last night. Dancer glances significantly at Paul, quickens the pace o interrogation,

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: Have you now changed your mind about Barney Quill? Do you now believe he raped Mrs. Manion?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I -- I don't know now, I think he might have.

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: When did you change your mind -- was it last night?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: No -- I-- it was here, this morning.

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: When were you given the panties? Was it last night?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Now wait a minute -- just wait a minute...

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE WEAVER
dialogues.text: Use the proper form of objection, Mr. Biegler. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: QQ. PAUL
dialogues.text: On second thought I don't object, Your Honor, I'd like the jury to hear her answer;

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE WEAVER
dialogues.text: Witness may answer,

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: No,.I was not given the panties last night or any other time. I found them, exactly like I said.

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: Do you know for a fact Barney Quill dropped the panties in the laundry chute or did you just assume it?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: ,l assumed it.

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: Had you thought that perhaps someone else might have dropped them there? Someone who wanted them found in the hotel laundry? .

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I hadn't thought about that.

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: And in the grip of what Mr. Biegler might call dissociative reaction you rushed in here with the panties because you wanted to crucify the character of the dead Barney Quill -- isn't that right?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: No, I felt it was my duty to...

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: Your pride was hurt, wasn't it?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I don't know what you mean,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Your honor, he's trying to confuse the witness. Let him ask questions that she can understand, a (CONTINUED)  196.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE WEAVER
dialogues.text: Yes, Mr. Dancer -- I'd like to know what you're getting at myself.

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: When you found the panties, Miss Pilant, was your first thought that Quill might have raped Mrs, Manion -- or was it that he might have been stepping out with Mrs, Manion?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: {to the Judge) What does he mean? I don't know what he means, ‘ JUDGE WEAVER Mr. Dancer, I must again ask you to put straight questions to the witness. —_ DANCER This is a straight question, Your Honor. Were you Barney Quill's mistress, Miss Pilant?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: (almost weeping with fury) No, no, I was not!

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: Do you know that it's common knowledge in Thunder Bay that you were living with Quill?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: That's not true. Barney Quill was -~

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was what, Miss Pilant? She looks helplessly at Paul. There's nothing he can do,

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: (continues) Barney Quill was what, Miss Pilant?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: (defiantly) He was my father, (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The courtroom whispers and mumbles. Dancer is stunned, He at Mary for a long moment, then spins to glare at Paul. P it straight, but he can't keep the triumphant glitter fro his eyes. Dancer relaxes, A smile touches his lips, He in his head in a tiny bow to Paul, ,

dialogues.speaker: DANCER
dialogues.text: No more questions, Your Honor,

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: That's all for me, Your Honor.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE WEAVER
dialogues.text: The witriess may step down, Mary leaves the stand, bravely, head up, Paul escorts her beside Parnell and Maida. :

dialogues.speaker: . JUDGE WEAVER
dialogues.text: {continues) We will recess for fifteen minutes ~~ after which we will hear the closing arguments. I hope the attorneys will be brief and to the point, If it's possible, I would like to charge the jury before nightfall. ‘ As the Judge is speaking, the CAMERA PULLS BACK to take i of the courtroom,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul is at the piano, aimlessly tinkering with some slow Parnell lies on the old couch, hat over his face. Maida c the kitchen, carrying a cup.of coffee, surveys the two me to peer through squinted eyes‘at the clock on Paul's desk one o'clock,

dialogues.speaker: MAIDA
dialogues.text: Think they're going to stay out all night? * (a pause) Why can't somebody say something?

dialogues.speaker: PARNELL
dialogues.text: (lifting the hat off his face a few inches) What shall I talk about, Maida darling? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MAIDA
dialogues.text: Tell me we're going to win. I'm counting on getting that promissory note from the Lieutenant. Ihope we can borrow some money on it. I need a new typewriter. Half the time the ‘p' and the 'f' won't strike on mine. ‘Party of the first part! sometimes comes out, ‘arty o' the irst art. ' it doesn't make sense. It's embarrassing.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Arty o' the ‘irst art, I like that. It has a ring to it. A moment passes,

dialogues.speaker: PARNELL
dialogues.text: (puts his hat over his eyes) Twelve people go off into a room. Twelve different hearts, twelve different minds, from twelve different walks of life -- twelve sets of eyes and ears, shapes and sizes -- And these twelve people have to judge another human being as different from them as they are from each other -- and in their judgment they must become of one mind <= unanimous, It's one of the miracles of man's disorganized soul that they can do it -- and most of the time do it right well, God bless juries. A little time passes. Paul picks at the keyboard, Maida s coffee. : .

dialogues.speaker: MAIDA
dialogues.text: I don't know what I'd do if I were on that jury. I really dont know. Do you?

dialogues.speaker: PARNELL
dialogues.text: (chuckles) I loved that, Polly, my boy. I loved that humble country lawyer bit. You had Mr. Dancer dancing. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: rs

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I'm afraid he got the last dance -- best summary I've ever heard in a courtroom,

dialogues.speaker: MAIDA
dialogues.text: I liked yours much better, Polly.

dialogues.speaker: PARNELL
dialogues.text: Do you have to play that stuff? Can't you play Danny Boy or Sweet Isle of Innisfree? Paul boogies Danny Boy and Parnell rises irately.

dialogues.speaker: PARNELL
dialogues.text: (continue s) Sacrilege! ~ —_—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The RING of the phone cuts into the racket Paul is making piano. He stops playing suddenly. He and Parnell turn tow Maida who has seized the phone,

dialogues.speaker: MAIDA
dialogues.text: (into phone) Paul Biegler's office... Yes sir. Right away. (she hangs up) They're ready,

dialogues.speaker: EXT, COURTHOUSE
dialogues.text: The upper floor, the courtroom floor, is ablaze with ligh is deserted, There are maybe fifteen cars parked in the s A water truck passes by spraying the pavement. As the tru itis joined by Paul's car which turns into-the curb befor house. Paul, Maida and Parnell hurry up the walk toward t entrance,

dialogues.speaker: INT, COURTHOUSE ROTUNDA
dialogues.text: The rotunda is dimly illuminated by a few lights in the c the rotunda, Light from above touches the marble stairs a above Laura's voice is heard murmuring a plaintive song - lazy. She is preceded by Muff -- flashlight in mouth, bou the stairs. As Laura comes into view, Paul, Maida and Par enter the courthouse. Laura sees them and halts, leaning stair wall. She carriesher shoes in her hand, her suit ja unbuttoned. She's pleasantly tight, careless and appealin

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Hi, sweetie.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (to Parnell and Maida) Be right up, They go on up, looking back suspiciously at tipsy Laura.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (continues) The jury's coming in,

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: (she hiccups) Iheard, Tell my loving husband I'L be waiting in the car.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: You're sure he'll be coming out?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: (putting on her shoes) Sure. He's lucky. Some people have all the luck. Tell him I'm waiting to get kicked to kingdom come, She meanders on down the stairs for a few steps.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: (continues) ’ Oh, hey sweetie... (she opens her purse, takes out a folded object, tosses it to Paul) Souvenir for you, The object in Paul's hand is a girdle.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (stepping down, hands her the girdle) Better keep it. You might need it again sometime, You never know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, you don't, do you? I like you, Polly. A beat, then she smiles and dawdles on, murmuring her son crosses the rotunda. Muff playing about her in circles, P her go with pity, amusement and affection.  ill

dialogues.speaker: INT, COURTROOM
dialogues.text: The wall clock reads 1:30. Only a few spectators have kep the newspapermen are, of course, still on hand, Mitch and are chatting with a couple of reporters and the court off lounging about inside the bar. There is a patter of conve air of expectancy. Manion enters with Sheriff Battisfore lawyers' conference room, As Paul enters the courtroom th main doors and walks down the center aisle, Judge Weaver from his chambers, The courtroom comes to attention as th climbs to his bench, He glances up at the clock, checking his watch,

dialogues.speaker: . JUDGE WEAVER
dialogues.text: You may be seated. Is everyone present, Mr. Sheriff?

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF
dialogues.text: Yes sir. All the principals are present.

dialogues.speaker: "JUDGE WEAVER
dialogues.text: Allow the jury to come in please. Sheriff Battisfore opens the door to the jury room, sayin right, folks, '' and the jury files in, tired, rumpled, t needing shaves,

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE WEAVER
dialogues.text: (continues; when the jury is seated) I warn all of these present not to interrupt the taking of the verdict. I will stop the proceedings and clear the courtroom if there is any demonstration, Proceed, Mr. Clerk.

dialogues.speaker: COURT CLERK
dialogues.text: Members of the jury, have you agreed upon a:verdict, and, if so, who will. _. ., Speak for you? ‘A JURYMAN rises.

dialogues.speaker: JURYMAN
dialogues.text: We have agreed. I'm the elected foreman,

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE WEAVER
dialogues.text: The defendant will rise. Manion stands at the counsel table.

dialogues.speaker: COURT CLERK
dialogues.text: What is your verdict, Mr, Foreman? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: lil 202.

dialogues.speaker: JURYMAN
dialogues.text: We find -- (his voice cracks and he clears his throat) We find the defendant not guilty by reason of insanity.

dialogues.speaker: EXT, OPEN HIGHWAY
dialogues.text: Paul's car comes speeding along the road by the lake whic to Thunder Bay. The sun is bright and it's a good day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul is driving, Parnell beside him, Both are mellow and

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Maida gave you the promissory note, didn't she?

dialogues.speaker: PARNELL
dialogues.text: (tapping his coat pocket) Right here -~ ready to be signed by our happy client. {lie looks out the window) You know, I used to think the world looked better through a glass of rye. It doesn't, I think I'll keep it this way. Looks nice.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I've gotten one good thing out of this case -- that's a law partner -- if it's all right with him,

dialogues.speaker: PARNELL
dialogues.text: (delighted) He'll be mighty proud to have his name on a shingle with yours, They grin at each other.

dialogues.speaker: EXT, GATE OF THUNDER BAY TOURIST PARK
dialogues.text: Paul's car hums from down the highway, turns through the

dialogues.speaker: EXT, SITE OF MANION'S TRAILER
dialogues.text: A littered clearing, waste paper blowing about the area, chair with a broken back has been left behind, a big oil as a garbage can and is overflowing with cans and empty b Paul's car rolls up and stops, Paul and Parnell get out. slowly to where the trailer once stood, looks about in di Lemon comes hurrying down from the trailer street,

dialogues.speaker: LEMON
dialogues.text: I guess you're looking for Lieutenant Manion, aren't you,. Mr. Biegler?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: LEMON
dialogues.text: He gave me this note for you. Paul takes the note, reads it silently.

dialogues.speaker: LEMON
dialogues.text: Felt real sorry for Mrs. Manion, She was crying, Left a mess, didn't they? I better get my helper busy here. He trots away. Without a word Paul hands Parnell the note lack of something else to do, idles over toward the oil d scans the note. Now he reads aloud.

dialogues.speaker: PARNELL
dialogues.text: (reading) © 'Dear Mr. Biegler: So sorry but Ihad to leave suddenly. I was seized by -- an irresistible impulse. Frederick Manion, ' The wind rustles through the littered camp site. Paul rea the oil drum and lifts out a red slipper with a spike hee has been broken and dangles from its joint. He sets the h Place, holds the slipper on the palm of his hand.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: How the devil are we going to face Maida?

dialogues.speaker: PARNELL
dialogues.text: {picking up an empty bottle) Gin. I knew there was something wrong with that fellow. Never saw a gin drinker you could trust. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Q PAUL
dialogues.text: Pardner, let's go see our first client.

dialogues.speaker: PARNELL
dialogues.text: And who might that be?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (grinning) Mary Pilant, We're going to administer - Barney Quill's estate,

dialogues.speaker: PARNELL
dialogues.text: (chuckles) That's what I call poetic justice for everybody. A little sadly, Paul drops the red slipper on top of the - PAUL. Yes, They get into the car and drive away. Now they're gone an remains -- the last dismembered part <- is the broken red lying among the empty bottles, FADE OUT. ©
